    Metabolism by Aldehyde Oxidase: Drug Design and Complementary Approaches to Challenges in Drug Discovery

    • Nenad Manevski*
      Nenad Manevski
      UCB Celltech, 208 Bath Road, Slough SL13WE, United Kingdom
      *Phone: +447901253248. E-mail: [email protected]

    SUBJECTS:

    Get e-Alerts

    Abstract

    Aldehyde oxidase (AO) catalyzes oxidations of azaheterocycles and aldehydes, amide hydrolysis, and diverse reductions. AO substrates are rare among marketed drugs, and many candidates failed due to poor pharmacokinetics, interspecies differences, and adverse effects. As most issues arise from complex and poorly understood AO biology, an effective solution is to stop or decrease AO metabolism. This perspective focuses on rational drug design approaches to modulate AO-mediated metabolism in drug discovery. AO biological aspects are also covered, as they are complementary to chemical design and important when selecting the experimental system for risk assessment. The authors’ recommendation is an early consideration of AO-mediated metabolism supported by computational and in vitro experimental methods but not an automatic avoidance of AO structural flags, many of which are versatile and valuable building blocks. Preferably, consideration of AO-mediated metabolism should be part of the multiparametric drug optimization process, with the goal to improve overall drug-like properties.

    1. Introduction

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Aldehyde oxidase (AO, EC1.2.3.1) is a cytosolic molybdenum-containing enzyme involved in the biotransformation of numerous drugs and xenobiotics.(1−5) Although structurally similar to xanthine oxidoreductase (XO),(6) AO has a significantly broader substrate selectivity and can catalyze four distinct reactions types: oxidations of azaheterocycles,(7) oxidations of aldehydes,(8) hydrolysis of amides,(9) and various reductions.(10,11) Each reaction type presents a unique set of challenges and opportunities in drug discovery and development (Table 1). Oxidations of azaheterocycles have been reported to contribute to high metabolic clearance and interspecies differences, resulting in the termination of several drug discovery programs in the past, including carbazeran,(12) BIBX1382,(13) and Lu AF09535.(14) AO-mediated oxidations of aldehydes in vitro have been described previously, both for endogenous and xenobiotic substrates, but their impact on drug disposition was recognized only recently (e.g., imrecoxib).(8,15) Hydrolysis of amides by AO, first described in 2015,(9) has also been found to contribute to high metabolic clearance and, depending on the drug of interest, a release of aryl-amine fragments that may be prone to bioactivation. Finally, AO-catalyzed reductions are diverse, affecting mainly nitro, N-oxide, and isoxazole moieties and are mainly of interest from the perspective of bioactivation.(16)
    Table 1. Selected Examples of AO-Related Challenges Experienced in Drug Discovery and Development
    compoundreaction typeobserved challengesref
    carbazeranoxidation of azaheterocyclehigh metabolic clearance in humans due to oxidations by AO(12)
    BIBX1382(13)
    FK3453(17)
    Lu AF09535(14)
    RO-1(18)
    JNJ-38877605oxidation of azaheterocyclerenal toxicity in humans due to accumulation of insoluble AO metabolite; renal toxicity had not been observed in nonclinical studies in rats and dogs(19)
    SGX523 high clearance in humans due to AO metabolism; renal toxicity in humans due to accumulation of insoluble AO metabolite(20,21)
    momelotiniboxidation of azaheterocycledisproportionate human metabolite due to oxidations by AO [metabolites in safety testing (MIST) issue](22)
    BILR 355oxidation of azaheterocycledisproportionate human metabolite due to oxidations by AO (MIST issue)(23)
    imidazoquinoline-containing cancer Osaka thyroid kinase inhibitorsoxidation of azaheterocyclerapid metabolism by AO in rats prevents pharmacological studies(24)
    pyridine-containing toll-like receptor subtype 7 agonistoxidation of azaheterocyclerapid metabolism by AO in rats prevents toxicological studies(7)
    VX-509 (decernotinib)oxidation of azaheterocycleAO metabolite is a time-dependent inhibitor of CYP3A4, leading to clinically relevant drug−drug interactions(25)
    dantrolenereduction of nitro groupbioactivation via AO-mediated nitro reduction and subsequent liver injury(26)
    imrecoxibaldehyde oxidationin vitro−in vivo disconnect in metabolite abundance due to AO-mediated aldehyde oxidation(8)
    GDC-0834hydrolysis of amidehigh metabolic clearance in humans due to AO-mediated amide hydrolysis(9)
    The challenge represented by AO-mediated metabolism is driven by several overlapping factors, including the complex biology of the enzyme (section 7), the widespread use of structural motifs that are AO substrates (e.g., azaheterocycle and amides), and common approaches to reduce cytochrome P450 (CYP)-mediated metabolism [e.g., reduction of log D and introduction of electron-withdrawing groups (EWG)]. The limited understanding of AO biology compared to other drug-metabolizing enzymes, such as CYPs or UDP-glucuronosyltransferases (UGTs), makes it a challenge to accurately predict human pharmacokinetics (PK) of drug candidates primarily metabolized by AO, which is reflected by the small number of marketed drugs that are AO substrates. Until a better understanding of AO activity in various tissues, and of how this is affected by genetic polymorphisms and extrinsic factors, is established for humans and nonclinical species, compounds with lower AO-mediated clearance and diversified biotransformation pathways are more likely predicted to have an acceptable human PK and safety. Therefore, it is essential to identify, assess, and modify structural features of drug candidates that lead to AO-mediated metabolism so that elimination pathways can be diversified to include other xenobiotic-metabolizing enzymes.
    This perspective focuses on rational drug design approaches to control AO metabolism, either by mitigation (e.g., stop, decrease, diversify) or utilization (e.g., design of a prodrug or a modified scaffold) of the enzymatic reaction. AO-mediated xenobiotic metabolism has been extensively reported previously by various groups, but only a few reviews and perspectives focused on drug design have been published,(7,27,28) often discussing exclusively AO-mediated oxidations. The authors’ motivation arose from our experience at UCB and published examples showing that AO-mediated metabolism is best approached at the drug design stage(7,24,29) as an integral part of the multiparametric optimization process to increase the overall drug-like properties of the compound. Later, during the drug development stage, approaches to assess and predict AO-mediated metabolism in humans are also possible and have been applied, but success has been limited due to an insufficient understanding of AO biology, which has often resulted in poor predictions of human PK by in vitro−in vivo extrapolation (IVIVE) or allometric scaling.
    The rational drug design aspect of this review focuses on arguably the most common reaction catalyzed by AO in the drug-like chemical space,(28) namely the AO-mediated oxidations of electron-deficient azaheterocycles via a nucleophilic mechanism (see graphical abstract). Oxidations of azaheterocycles were historically perceived mainly as a risk for high metabolic clearance in humans. Recent examples have significantly broadened this view to include evidence for renal toxicity due to the formation of insoluble crystalline metabolites,(19,20) metabolites in safety testing (MIST)-related issues,(22,30) interspecies differences,(7,24) as well as AO-derived metabolites leading to time-dependent inactivation of CYP3A4 (vide infra).(25) Despite these discouraging examples, AO should not be perceived as an enemy of drug design teams. Oxidative metabolites formed by AO are often metabolically stable (authors’ unpublished observations) and, if pharmacologically active, may provide valuable inspiration for novel scaffolds and improved drug design.(31) On the other hand, high turnover of AO substrates enables the potential for a prodrug approach, as exemplified by 5-fluoro-2-pyrimidinone,(32) famciclovir,(33) and fasudil.(34) In addition, the current perspective will also cover reactions of aldehyde oxidation, amide hydrolysis, and reductions, albeit in less detail, proportional to the number of examples available in the literature. For these reactions, focus will often be placed on safety and drug developability (e.g., interspecies difference and MIST) not high metabolic clearance per se.
    Although designing away from, or at least reducing, the propensity of drug candidates to be metabolized by AO is desirable in drug discovery, the task faced by design teams is difficult. First, AO structural flags are very common (e.g., azaheterocycles and amides), usually covering a large proportion of the chemical space (see section 3.1). Second, due to opposing catalytic mechanisms (e.g., electrophilic vs nucleophilic oxidation), common strategies to reduce oxidative metabolism (especially if CYP-mediated) will usually favor AO-mediated metabolism.(7) Third, directly blocking sites susceptible to attack by AO with bulky groups may alter key pharmacophores and erode ligand efficiency by increasing the molecular weight and log D, ultimately degrading the overall drug-like properties.(35) Therefore, designing away from AO-mediated metabolism requires a thoughtful approach based on understanding and application of several overlapping factors (Figure 1), including the catalytic mechanism, substrate specificity, structure−activity relationship (SAR) with the therapeutic target, AO biology, and various supporting tools (e.g., computational and experimental methods to assess metabolism by AO). Although the focus is on human AO, examples of AO-mediated metabolism in nonclinical species are also provided, especially when available human data are limited and interspecies differences played a major role in the decision making. Emphasis is also placed on preservation of the key drug-like properties, including lipophilicity, solubility, permeability, ligand efficiency, and recognition and (if possible) removal of known structural alerts.
    A summary of factors influencing AO drug design is presented in Figure 1. Section 2 covers the structure and catalytic mechanisms of AO, providing a rational basis for further discussion. Reactions catalyzed by AO and their substrate specificity are covered in section 3, including examples of oxidation, hydrolysis, and reduction. Section 4 explores computational approaches to evaluate metabolism by AO, even before the compound is synthesized. Section 5 summarizes key chemical design approaches to control AO-mediated metabolism, including methods to stop, decrease, or utilize AO-catalyzed reactions. Section 6 is dedicated to examples of drug discovery programs that tackled AO metabolism, providing a valuable insight into challenges, pitfalls, and opportunities encountered by design teams. Finally, section 7 and 8 provide in-depth information about AO biology, including reported suggestions of AO as a therapeutic target and experimental assessment, complementing the drug design approaches.

    2. Enzyme Structure and Catalytic Mechanism of AO

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Understanding of AO structure and catalytic mechanism is important to support rational drug design. Additionally, it is beneficial to appreciate differences and similarities between AO and other key drug-metabolizing enzymes (e.g., CYPs and various hydrolases) so that medicinal chemistry design can be driven on a balance of overall biotransformation liabilities.

    2.1. Structure of Human AO

    Human AO is a butterfly shaped homodimer with approximate dimensions of 150 Å × 90 Å × 65 Å (Figure 2A).(2,3,37) Each monomer can be further divided into three distinct domains: (I) a small N-terminal domain (20 kDa), which harbors the two [2Fe-2S] clusters, (II) the central domain with flavin adenine dinucleotide (FAD) cofactor stacked between two leucine residues (40 kDa), and (III) the large C-terminal domain (90 kDa) containing the molybdenum pyranopterin cofactor (MoCo) and the substrate binding site (for reactions of oxidation and hydrolysis; reductions likely occur at the FAD-binding site(3,10)). The three domains are connected by two linker regions bridging domains I/II and domains II/III.(2)
    Substrate access to and product release from the MoCo active site are governed by a funnel that leads into the active site cavity.(37) Features of this funnel are defined by two flexible loops on the surface of the protein, gates 1 and 2, and the amino acid composition of these loops may explain unique substrate specifies of various mammalian AO enzymes.(3,37) Gate 1 is predominantly composed of hydrophobic residues, whereas gate 2 is a short, dynamic loop characterized by the presence of residue Phe885, the second residue after the gate, which interacts with the substrate molecule, oriening it toward the catalytic site.(3,37) At the MoCo active site (reactions of oxidations and hydrolysis), important and conserved residues are Glu1270, Phe923, Lys893, and Gln776.(37) Glu1270 and Lys893 are believed to be directly involved in the catalytic mechanism by providing hydrogen bonding to stabilize the transition state (see section 2.2). On the other hand, two conserved aromatic residues, Phe885 and Phe923, are likely important for the substrate orientation toward the MoCo.(37) In addition to the MoCo active site, human AO is thought to have an allosteric inhibitor binding site (occupied by thioridazine in the available crystal structure)(37) and FAD active site responsible for reduction reactions.(3,10) The structure, sequence conservation, single nucleotide polymorphisms, and evolution of mammalian AO and related proteins have been extensively reviewed elsewhere.(3,4,38)

    2.2. Catalytic Mechanism of AO

    Although catalyzed by the same enzyme, reactions of oxidation, hydrolysis, and reduction by AO have a few differences that deserve to be clarified. Moreover, it is worth highlighting differences between AO and other common drug-metabolizing enzymes, especially CYPs, flavin-containing monooxygenases (FMOs), and hydrolytic enzymes.

    2.2.1. Reactions of Oxidation

    In the first step, the site of oxidation, i.e., the electrophilic carbon of the azaheterocycle or aldehyde, is attacked by the nucleophilic −OH ligand of the MoCo ligand (MoVI), likely further activated by Glu1270 (Figure 3A, step i). According to the concerted mechanism hypothesis, hydride transfer to MoCo’s sulfido ligand occurs simultaneously (via a tetrahedral intermediate) to form a transition state stabilized by hydrogen bonding from Glu1270 and Lys893.(39,40) The concerted mechanism is supported by the enzyme kinetic studies (N-substituted heterocycles and deuterium isotope effects) and density functional theory calculations(36,40,41) (see section 4 for more details). Hydride abstraction and transfer to S of MoCo is likely the rate-limiting step in the formation of the transition stage,(42,43) opening a possibility for the kinetic deuterium isotope effects (KDIE) to decrease the rate of AO-catalyzed oxidations (section 5.3). In the second step (Figure 3B, step ii), a molecule of water hydrolyzes the transition state intermediate, releasing the oxidized product and the reduced MoCo (MoIV). Within each catalytic cycle, oxygen from MoCo is incorporated into the substrate and additional oxygen from H2O replenishes the vacant coordination position on the MoCo. As illustrated in Figure 3, the oxygen that is incorporated into the product is derived from one of two sources: the initial −OH ligand of the MoCo from AO in the first-turnover reaction and from H2O via MoCo in the subsequent reactions. The origin of oxygen from H2O enables experimental approaches that use 18O from H218O (see sections 8.1 and 8.3). The catalytic cycle is closed by the reoxidation of the MoCo (MoIV → MoVI) (Figure 3A, step iii). Two reducing equivalents (2e−) are transferred via two [2Fe−2S] clusters and the FAD cofactor to molecular oxygen as their final acceptor to generate superoxide and/or hydrogen peroxide.(44) In addition to molecular oxygen, the electron acceptor can be another molecule, including a xenobiotic, leading to AO-catalyzed reductions (see section 3.4 below).
    Although both AO and CYPs catalyze C atom hydroxylations, it is important to emphasize that catalytic mechanisms are different (or even contrasting), leading to unique substrate specificity and site of metabolism (SOM) on the drug-like compounds. Whereas AO-catalyzed oxidations occur by nucleophilic attack of the −OH group of the MoCo ligand (Figure 3A, step i), CYP-catalyzed oxidations are driven by the electrophilic attack of the activated oxygen species (perferryl oxygen complex FeO3+ or oxene, an electrophilic atom with only six electrons in the outer layer).(46,47) Similarly, FMOs catalyze oxidations of soft nucleophiles (e.g., basic amines and sulfides) by electrophilic attack of the 4a-hydroperoxyflavin moiety (FADH−OOH complex).(48) These differences play a profound role in drug design: whereas electron-deficient moieties will be largely protected from CYP- and FMO-catalyzed oxidations, this may leave them vulnerable to AO-catalyzed oxidations (see section 5). Examples of both CYPs and AO catalyzing the same reaction do exist, however, O6-benzylguanine is oxidized at the position 8 of the guanine by both CYP1A2 and AO.(49) Another interesting and useful difference between CYP- and AO-catalyzed oxidations is the origin of oxygen atom; whereas CYPs utilize oxygen from atmospheric O2,(46) AO uses oxygen from H2O.(50) This unique feature of the AO catalytic mechanisms can be used for analytic purposes, for example, in experiments with H218O to identify metabolites formed by AO.(51)

    2.2.2. Reactions of Hydrolysis

    On the basis of the example of the amide hydrolysis of GDC-0834,(9,28) the following catalytic mechanism was proposed (Figure 3B). The carbonyl group of the amide is attacked by the nucleophilic hydroxymolybdenum moiety to form a tetrahedral intermediate.(9) As this step requires a relatively strong nucleophile, the authors proposed the MoIV oxidative state,(9) instead of the MoVI involved in the AO-catalyzed oxidations (see above). This proposed mechanism, like AO-catalyzed reductions, would require accumulation of the enzyme in the MoIV oxidative state, probably by the previous oxidation of another compound, either endogenous or exogenous.(9) The formed tetrahedral intermediate yields the free amine (M1) and possibly ester bound to molybdenum, which is further hydrolyzed to release the free acid metabolite (M2) and the free MoIV hydroxymolybdenum (Figure 3B).(9,28) Amide hydrolysis is also catalyzed by various hydrolytic enzymes, including amidases, esterases, and peptidases.(52) Although hydrolases are a diverse group of enzymes, the general catalytic mechanism of hydrolysis is fairly preserved; a nucleophilic group of the enzyme (e.g., −OH of serine, −SH of cysteine, or activated H2O) attacks the carbonyl C atom of the amide, while an electrophilic group at the active site polarizes the carbonyl C atom and the proton donor (H−B) facilitates leaving of the cleaved amine.(53)

    2.2.3. Reactions of Reduction

    In contrast to reactions of oxidation and hydrolysis, the catalytic mechanism of AO-catalyzed reductions is poorly understood. Historically, reactions of AO-mediated reduction were performed under specific incubation conditions: under anaerobic atmosphere and in the presence of electron donors such as 2-hydroxypyrimidine, N1-methylnicotine, benzaldehyde, or NADPH.(54,55) More recent results show that reductions by AO can also occur under aerobic conditions.(11) Regardless of the oxygen levels, AO-catalyzed reductions likely need to be coupled with an oxidation of another substrate (“electron donor”), either endogenous or exogenous.(10,26) Moreover, on the basis of recent enzyme kinetic evidence, AO-mediated reductions likely occur at a site distinct from the oxidative MoCo site,(10) either the FAD-binding site or near the [2Fe-2S] clusters.

    3. Substrate Specificity and Reactions Catalyzed

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    As described above, AO catalyzes four known reaction types: oxidations of azaheterocycles, oxidations of aldehydes, hydrolysis of amides, and various reductions. In this section, we will review structural features leading to these reactions based on published reports.

    3.1. Oxidation of Azaheterocycles

    Oxidations of azaheterocycle-containing drugs and drug candidates are the most common reactions catalyzed by AO (Table 1). Oxidations usually occur at the electron-deficient sp2 carbons adjacent to nitrogen, which are part of aromatic azaheterocycles (−CH═N− moiety) or nonaromatic charged azaheterocycles (−CH═N+< moiety, iminium ions). AO has a significantly broader substrate specificity than the closely related enzyme xanthine oxidoreductase (XO), which is mainly restricted to the metabolism of hypoxanthine and xanthine in catabolism of purines.(56)

    3.1.1. Oxidations of Aromatic Azaheterocycles

    A large variety of aromatic azaheterocycles and fused heteroaromatic systems were reported to be oxidized by AO, generally resulting in pyridone-like metabolites (Figure 4, Table 2). Although prevalence of AO structural alerts was not fully investigated, 56% of Pfizer’s kinase-targeted compounds,(57) and 36% of all ChEMBL-reported drugs (authors’ unpublished observations; https://www.ebi.ac.uk/chembl/g/#browse/drugs, last accessed in June 2018(58)) were predicted to be potential substrates for AO. The sites of oxidations are predominantly carbons adjacent to nitrogen, although important exceptions are quinoline,(30) pyridazine (authors’ observations), cinnoline,(59) acridine,(60) and cryptoleptine motifs,(61) where oxidations are also observed at distant carbons (Figure 4). The susceptibility to oxidations by AO generally increases with nitrogen count, especially if the affected carbon is between two nitrogens; for instance, pyrimidine oxidations are more commonly reported than pyridine oxidations. Conversely, oxidations of phenyl analogues or heterocycles without nitrogen are not reported at all, even if electron-deficient carbons near electron-withdrawing group (EWG) are present. On the basis of literature reports, some common heterocycles like pyrimidine, quinoline, and purine have a high likelihood of being AO substrates, indicating that such chemotypes should always be tested for AO activity (Table 2). The impact of overall molecular size and geometry is difficult to estimate without complementary docking approaches, but reported AO substrates have widely different sizes ranging from 130 Da (quinoline) to 823 Da (quinoline-containing azetidinyl ketolide).(62) Analysis of published AO oxidative substrates also indicates that successful clinical progression is still possible (Table 2, marked in bold typeface), although comparatively rare (e.g., imatinib,(63) AMG900,(63) lenvantinib,(64) etc.).
    Table 2. Selected Examples of Common Azaheterocycles Oxidized by AOc
    a

    Drugs currently on the market.

    b

    For fasudil(34) and famciclovir(34) (both prodrugs), high metabolic clearance by AO is not a liability as the AO-formed oxidative metabolite is active.

    c

    Exact sites of oxidation by AO, if specified in the literature, are marked with an asterisk. Compounds that failed in human clinical trials due to poor PK or related issues are underlined. Compounds that have acceptable human PK despite being AO substrates are marked in bold.

    The size of an azaheterocyclic ring also plays an important role, especially in nonfused systems, with 6-membered rings being more prone to AO-mediated oxidations than 5-membered rings. Exceptions to this observation are the reported oxidations of oxazoles(109) and benzothiazole.(110) Various nitrogen-containing fused heteroaromatics, both in 6,6 and 6,5 arrangements, are also commonly reported as AO substrates (Figure 4, Table 2). The sites of oxidation by AO in such systems are less predictable and generally occur on carbons adjacent to nitrogens in both 6- and 5-membered rings. Oxidations of fused heteroaromatic 5,5 systems are not reported, however, indicating a possibility for AO-mitigating design of molecules.
    The susceptibility to oxidations by AO may be modulated by ring substitutions. On the basis of the nucleophilic catalytic mechanism and published SAR examples, the consensus is that EWG and electron-donating (EDG) groups usually enhance and reduce oxidations by AO, respectively.(28,79,82,111) Examples of azaheterocycles where both EWG and EDG are present are more difficult to predict and complementary computational approaches are recommended (see section 4) to help design and decision-making. However, some EDG ring substituents may enhance AO-mediated oxidations by facilitating binding to the enzyme, even if electronics of the affected carbon would suggest otherwise.(75−77) Broad interspecies differences in azaheterocyclic substrate specificity between human and rodent AO have been reported, most likely due to differences in AO isoforms expressed, their tissue distribution, and their binding site properties; this will be discussed in more detail in sections 7 and 8.

    3.1.2. Oxidation of Nonaromatic Azaheterocycles (Iminium Ions)

    In addition to the typical oxidations of aromatic heterocycles, several authors reported AO involvement in oxidations of nonaromatic heterocycles, often after initial oxidation by another drug-metabolizing enzyme like monoamine oxidase B (MAO-B) and CYPs. The piperazine ring of KW-2449, a multikinase inhibitor developed for treatment of leukemia, was oxidized to iminium ion by MAO-B and then by AO to the pharmacodynamically active piperazinone metabolite (Figure 5A).(112) The iminium ion intermediate of KW-2449 was also an irreversible inhibitor of AO, possibly through covalent binding to the enzyme.(113) A similar metabolic pathway was observed for 1-methyl-4-phenyl-1,2,3,6-tetrahydropyridine (MPTP), a dopaminergic pro-neurotoxin which induces parkinsonism in humans and other primates (Figure 5B).(114,115) The morpholine ring of momelotinib, an inhibitor of Janus kinase 1/2 and activin A receptor type 1, was first oxidized by CYPs to iminium ion and then by AO to the corresponding morpholin-3-one metabolite (Figure 5C).(22) In contrast to the low levels observed in rat and dog plasma (<10% of drug-related material), morpholin-3-one was the most abundant circulating metabolite in human plasma (64.2% of drug-related material), leading to a MIST issue that was resolved only by subsequent administration of the isolated metabolite to rats.(22) AO-mediated oxidations of the corresponding iminium ions to lactams were also reported for several older pyrrolidines-containing drugs, including nicotine, tremorine, and prolintane.(5)

    3.2. Oxidation of Aldehydes

    The oxidation of aldehydes to carboxylic acids can be catalyzed by several enzymes with an overlapping substrate selectivity, most notably aldehyde dehydrogenase (ALDH), AO, and XO. Although aldehydes are rarely present in therapeutic drugs, this functional group can be formed as an intermediate after oxidation of primary alcohols [by alcohol dehydrogenase (ADH)] or terminal methyl group (by CYPs). Retinal and pyridoxal are examples of endogenous aldehydes oxidized by AO (Figure 6A).(116,117) Study of vanillin, isovanillin, and protocatechuic aldehyde oxidations found that vanillin was rapidly oxidized by AO (in guinea pig liver), whereas isovanillin was mainly oxidized by ALDH and protocatechuic aldehyde was oxidized by all three tested enzymes (AO, ALDH, and XO) (Figure 6B).(118,119) Further studies with a set of 11 benzaldehydes confirmed that AO plays an important role in the metabolism of aromatic aldehydes.(120)
    Imrecoxib, a cyclooxygenase-2 inhibitor, has a benzylic methyl group that is oxidized to carboxylic acid, a major metabolite in human plasma (Figure 6C).(8) In vitro studies revealed that oxidations to alcohol and aldehyde are catalyzed by CYP3A4 and CYP2D6, but subsequent oxidation to carboxylic acid is predominantly catalyzed by AO.(8) Lu AA21004, a multimodal antidepressant in clinical development was first oxidized by CYP2D6 to benzyl-alcohol and then by ADH, ALDH, and AO to benzoic acid (Figure 6D).(15) Further examples of AO-mediated oxidations of intermediate aldehydes include serotonin, citalopram, tamoxifen, and cyclophosphamide.(5)

    3.3. Amide Hydrolysis

    GDC-0834, an amide-containing Bruton’s tyrosine kinase inhibitor, was hydrolyzed more extensively in humans compared to nonclinical species (Figure 7A), triggering a number of mechanistic assays to identify the responsible enzyme.(9) Enzymatic assays and proteomic analysis revealed that AO and carboxylesterase were both involved, whereas in silico modeling suggested that the amide bond of GDC-0834 binds near the MoCo, potentially enabling nucleophilic attack on the carbonyl of the amide bond by the hydroxyl of MoCo.(9) This novel reaction of amide hydrolysis by AO raised concerns not only because of high metabolic clearance and ubiquity of amide bonds in drug-like compounds, but also due to the potential formation of aryl-amines (anilines) as hydrolysis products of aromatic amides, metabolites that carry a significant genotoxic risk.(121)
    SAR of AO-catalyzed hydrolysis was explored with a set of 75 synthetic amides, including various aromatic and aliphatic analogues (Figure 7B,C).(28) In general, aromatic amides were more susceptible to AO hydrolysis, and structure of the amine part of the amide bond (aniline moiety) had a greater impact on the hydrolysis rates. Substitutions of aniline moieties in meta positions with EDG and EWG groups increased and decreased propensity toward AO hydrolysis, respectively. Substitutions of ortho and para positions generally reduced hydrolysis regardless if EDG or EWG was introduced. Tertiary amides, sterically hindered and less flexible anilines or aliphatic amines, were also generally stable (Figure 7B).(28) In contrast to aniline moiety, the structure of acyl moiety generally had less impact on the hydrolysis rates: furane, indole, 2-methylenindole, (3-fluorophenyl)propane, cyclohexane, pyrazine, and pyridine were all substrates (Figure 7C).(28) Tested bis-aliphatic amides were generally not substrates.(28)

    3.4. Reductions

    AO is known to catalyze reductions of nitro groups, N-oxides, sulfoxides, isoxazoles, isothiazoles, nitrite, and hydroxamic acids (Table 3). In contrast to oxidative metabolism, reductions catalyzed by AO require an electron donor, commonly 2-hydroxypyrimidine, N1-methylnicotine, benzaldehyde, or NADPH, likely occur at the FAD-binding site(10) and were historically thought to occur exclusively in anaerobic conditions.(54,55) However, recent studies challenged these views and showed that not only these reductions can occur under standard aerobic conditions in vitro but also that reduced metabolites are formed in vivo, contributing to metabolic clearance, interspecies differences, and safety profiles of drug-like compounds. Selected examples of AO-catalyzed reductions are shown in Table 3.
    Table 3. Examples of Reductions Catalyzed by AO
    compoundreaction catalyzedenzyme sourceincubation conditionsref
    2-nitrofluorene, 4-nitrobiphenyl, 1-nitronaphthalene, 1-nitropyrenenitro → amino or hydroxylaminerabbit liver cytosol and purified rabbit AOanaerobic(54)
    nitrazepamnitro → aminoHLCa and purified human AOaerobic(122)
    clonazepam, flunitrazepam, flutamide, nilutamide, nimesulidenitro → aminoHLCa and purified AOaerobic; N1-methylnicotinamide as electron donor(11)
    nimesulidenitro → aminohuman and rat liver cytosolaerobic(123)
    dantrolenenitro → aminoHLCaaerobic(26)
    imidaclopridnitro → amino or hydroxylamineliver cytosol and S9 fraction from various speciesanaerobic(124)
    nitrite ion to nitric oxideNO2− → NOpurified rat liver AOanaerobic(125,126)
    imipramine N-oxide and nicotinamide N-oxideN-oxide → deoxy analoguesliver cytosol of rabbits, rats, mice, hamsters, and hogsanaerobic(55,127)
    quinoxaline N-oxidesquinoxaline-1,4-di-N-oxides → 1-deoxy analoguespurified porcine AOanaerobic(128)
    zonisamideisoxazole reductive ring openingliver cytosol from rabbits, hamsters, mice, rats, and guinea pigsanaerobic(129)
    ziprasidoneisothioazole reductive ring openingHLCaaerobic, 2-hydroxpyrimidine as electron donor(130)
    oximes of acetophenone, salicylic acid, and camphoroxime → ketimines → ketones (nonenzymatic)rabbit liver cytosolanaerobic(131)
    hydroxamic acidshydroxamic acids → amidesrabbit liver cytosolanaerobic(132)
    sulindacsulfoxide → sulfideguinea pig liver AOanaerobic(133)
    a

    HLC, human liver cytosol.

    3.4.1. Reduction of Nitro Compounds

    Comparable to amide hydrolysis, reduction of nitro group leads to formation of hydroxylamines and primary amines. These metabolites may undergo metabolic bioactivation, potentially contributing to a range of adverse drug reactions.(121) A study with rabbit liver cytosol and purified rabbit AO, performed under anaerobic conditions and in the presence of electron donors, showed that carcinogenic 2-nitrofluorene, 4-nitrobiphenyl, 1-nitronaphthalene, and 1-nitropyrene were reduced to the corresponding hydroxylamines and/or amines (Figure 8A).(54) Similarly, nitrazepam, a nitro-containing benzodiazepine hypnotic, was primarily reduced by AO to 7-amino-nitrazepam (Figure 8B) under aerobic conditions, a metabolite that is subsequently acetylated and thought to be involved in liver injury and teratogenicity of nitrazepam.(122) Nitro reduction was more prominent in human liver cytosol (HLC) compared to microsomes and increased by 50% with inclusion of NADPH; subsequent purification of the enzymatically active fraction confirmed involvement of AO.(122) Nimesulide, a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug, was reduced by rat and human AO to amino-nimesulide, a metabolite that further undergoes CYP oxidations and GSH trapping and contributes to hepatotoxicity of nimesulide (Figure 8C).(123) To assess AO involvement, incubations were performed in human and rat liver cytosol under aerobic conditions and activity was inhibited by estradiol,(123) a steroid previously reported to be a potent AO inhibitor.(134) The nitro group of dantrolene, a skeletal muscle relaxant, was also reduced by AO under aerobic conditions and in the presence of electron donors (NADPH or N1-methylnicotineamide) to form an aminodantrolene, a metabolite that is further acetylated and N-hydroxylated, resulting in metabolic bioactivation and liver injury (Figure 8D).(26) Safety risks of AO-mediated nitro reductions were highlighted in studies of imidacloprid metabolism, a widely used neonicotinoid insecticide whose nitro-imine group is reduced to nitroso-imine and hydrazine metabolites (Figure 8E).(16,124,135) In vitro studies of imidacloprid metabolism found that nitro reduction is catalyzed by AO across species that express the enzyme, especially in the presence of electron donors such as benzaldehyde or N1-methylnicotineamide.(124) Mechanistic studies in mice confirmed AO involvement in vivo, mainly through use of chemical inhibition (hydralazine and tungsten) and AO-deficient animals,(135) whereas a study in New Zealand rabbits found that imidacloprid induces a clastogenic effect (micronucleus assay) that is diminished by coadministration of tungsten as an AO inhibitor.(16)
    SAR of nitroaromatic reductions to aryl-amines was recently investigated in a set of 11 drugs; incubations were performed under aerobic conditions in human liver cytosol.(11) The study found that six compounds (clonazepam, flunitrazepam, flutamide, nilutamide, nimesulide, and nimetazepam) were significantly reduced by human AO, whereas the remaining five compounds either exhibited minor reduction (azelnidipine, nifedipine, and nimodipine) or were not affected (metronidazole and tolcapone).(11) Authors suggested that propensity toward nitro reduction is governed by electronic effects; relatively electron-rich nitro groups were more readily reduced compared to electron-deficient nitro groups.(11) In addition to organic nitro compounds, AO was found to catalyze the reduction of nitrite ion itself to nitric oxide (NO2− → NO), a mechanism that may contribute to NO formation under hypoxic conditions in human cells (see also section 7.3).(126)
    To elucidate interplay between oxidative and reductive metabolism of AO under standard aerobic conditions, 5-nitroquinoline was incubated with human liver cytosol and recombinant human AO (Figure 9).(10) Incubations resulted in three metabolites, oxidized 5-nitroquinoline-2-on, reduced 5-aminoquinoline, and oxidized/reduced 5-aminoquinoline-2-one, whereas enzyme kinetic assays suggested presence of two distinct AO active sites, one for oxidations and second for reductions. These results suggested that nitro group in 5-nitroquinoline can compete favorably with oxygen for the AO reducing equivalents (see section 4).(10)

    3.4.2. Reductions of N-Oxides

    Imipramine N-oxide and nicotinamide N-oxide were reduced to imipramine and nicotinamide, respectively, under anaerobic conditions by liver cytosol of rabbits, rats, mice, hamsters, and hogs (Figure 10A).(55,127) Several quinoxaline-1,4-di-N-oxides (quinocetone, mequindox, and cyadox) were reduced to corresponding 1-deoxy analogues by porcine aldehyde oxidase under anaerobic conditions (Figure 10B).(128) Surprisingly, tirapazamine, an experimental anticancer compound that is activated to a toxic radical under anoxic conditions, was not reduced by human AO under anaerobic conditions and presence of benzaldehyde as an electron donor (Figure 10C).(136)

    3.4.3. Reductive Opening of Isoxazole and Isothiazole Rings

    Zonisamide, an isoxazole-containing anticonvulsant used to treat epilepsy and Parkinson’s disease, undergoes reductive cleavage of the isoxazole ring catalyzed by liver AO from rabbits, hamsters, mice, rats, and guinea pigs (Figure 11A).(129) Reactions were performed under anaerobic conditions, included an electron donor (2-hydroxypyrimidine or NADPH) and were inhibited by menadione.(129) Interestingly, AO was recently found to oxidize 2H-oxazoles to 2-oxazolones under aerobic conditions.(109) Ziprasidone, a 5-hydroxytryptamine-2A and dopamine-2 receptors antagonist, showed reductive opening of the isothiazole ring in aerobic incubations with human liver cytosol (Figure 11B).(130) Isothiazole reduction was enhanced by inclusion of electron donor (2-hydroxypyrimidine) and inhibited by menadione, indicating aldehyde oxidase involvement, and the reaction also proceeded nonenzymatically in the presence of reduced glutathione.(130,137)

    3.4.4. Other Examples of AO-Catalyzed Reductions

    Oximes of acetophenone, salicylic acid, and camphor were reduced to corresponding ketimines by rabbit liver cytosol under anaerobic conditions and presence of 2-hydroxypyrimidine as an electron donor (Figure 11C).(131) Authors proposed that formed ketimines undergo nonenzymatic hydrolysis to ketones or aldehydes with release of equimolar amount of ammonia.(131) A number of hydroxamic acids (salicylhydroxamic acid, benzohydroxamic acid, anthranilhydroxamic acid, and nicotinohydroxamic acid) were also reduced under anaerobic conditions to corresponding amides (Figure 11D).(132) Sulindac, a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug with a methyl-sulfoxide group, was reduced to corresponding sulfide by guinea pig liver aldehyde oxidase (Figure 11E).(133)

    4. Computational Approaches To Predict AO Metabolism

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Undeniably, it would be very useful for drug design if the likelihood, site, or rate of AO metabolism could be calculated from a chemical structure even before it is synthesized. Ever since there have been data on experimentally determined substrates, researchers have investigated how to tackle these tasks. How to identify the SOM on known substrates has also been subject of several studies. Research was predominantly performed on AO-mediated oxidations, leaving reactions of hydrolysis and reduction less explored.
    The earliest attempt at finding quantitative structure−metabolism relationships (QSMR) within AO substrates was carried out by Ghafourian and Rashidi.(83−85) They used a data set of Kms and Vmaxs of 14 and 15 substituted phthalazines and quinazolines, respectively. They did not find a consistent or global model for these two series, but they did conclude that reduced electron density at the SOM of the quinazolines was favored by the enzyme, consistent with the mechanism of action (MOA) and with later studies. Torres et al.(40) made the first attempt to predict the regioselectivity of AO substrates. A little surprisingly, given the results of later studies, they did not find the most positive carbon to be predictive of the SOM of eight drug substrates. Looking for a better method, the authors calculated the relative energies of tetrahedral intermediates (see proposed transition states in Figure 3) at each available position around the nitrogen-containing ring system.(40) In all but one of their test molecules, the SOM had the lowest energy. Jones and Korzekwa(138) produced a mechanistic model designed to predict the rate of intrinsic clearance by AO: predicted CLint,AO = A HrRel + B steric + C. They fitted parameters A, B, and C using seven known substrates. The HrRel is the relative energy of the tetrahedral intermediate compared to that of quinolone. At the time of this study, the structure of human AO had not been determined. Not deterred, the authors modeled the shape of the active site as a “reaction wedge” pseudomolecule. The steric accessibility of each substrate SOM was calculated with a molecular mechanics energy calculation after constrained minimization at fixed separations from this entity. Their results were mainly validated using an additional two compounds. This was a creative study, but as the authors point out, hamstrung by the very small training and validation sets and the unreliability of the experimental data. However, their “reaction wedge” was taken up by Xu et al.,(79) who modeled the likelihood that any given potential site of oxidation of an azaheterocycle using two parameters: ΔEinter and Steric, the former being the relative energy of the tetrahedral reaction intermediate and the latter a measure of steric hindrance. They constructed a decision tree using data on 35 compounds and validated it by testing 15 azaheterocycle containing c-Met inhibitors for AO metabolism. Their method proved correct for all but one compound, which was a false positive. Three others were correctly predicted as previously unidentified AO substrates and their SOM’s correctly identified. The Steric factor was decisive in nearly every instance.
    Different catalytic mechanisms were proposed and studied with density functional theory (DFT) calculations on simplified models by Montefiori et al.(36) Each reaction mechanism was found to be equally useful because the calculated transition state energies at different sites of a set of seven 6-substituted 4-quinazolinones were highly correlated. On balance of evidence, they decided the concerted mechanism, without prior deprotonation of MoCo, was the most likely.(36) They concluded that, although the SOM of a known substrate could be determined by the comparison of DFT calculated activation energies at all possible sites, this could also be determined much more quickly and easily with ESP (electrostatic potential) derived partial charges. The carbon with the most positive ESP charge in nitrogen containing heteroaromatic ring systems was most likely to be the SOM.
    Lepri at al.(28) provided a step change to studies on this subject by measuring the metabolism of 198 azo-aromatic ring system containing compounds and 75 amides in HLC and publishing the results. They then proceeded to examine the structure−metabolism relationships (SMR) that can be observed in this data, including insights from the results of DFT calculations and docking into the crystal structure of human AO in their analysis.(28) For the oxidation of azo-aromatic moieties, they found that the DFT calculated partial charges method is the best and most pragmatic approach for such large number of compounds. As suggested by Montefiori et al.,(36) the most positive unsubstituted carbon ortho to the nitrogen was usually found to be the SOM. Using FLAP (Molecular Discovery) for docking, they also found that substrates tended to occupy a productive binding pose more often than nonsubstrates. They also observed that pyridine, indole, and pyrazole tend to be shielded against AO metabolism. For the pyridine, all 18 examples tested were found not to be substrates, evidence for the benefit of the latter two ring systems is harder to discern. The authors conclude by suggesting the following strategies to protect against AO azo-aromatic oxidation:
    1.

    Substitution at the most positive carbon (adjacent to a nitrogen).

    2.

    Lower the partial charge of the most positive carbon by substituting elsewhere in the ring system. EDGs seem to help, except on pyrimidines.

    3.

    Add substituents that could hinder productive binding to the catalytic site.

    For AO mediated amide hydrolysis, they find that EWGs on the anilide moieties tend to be more stable following the order of stability ortho < meta < para. No statistics were produced to back-up these conclusions.(28)
    Cruciani et al.(111) extended this data set of experimentally measured AO metabolism to over 600 compounds, which they used to parametrize a computational tool (MetaSite, Molecular Discovery) for the prediction of the likelihood of metabolism by AO. To our knowledge, at the time of writing, this is the only available packaged computational tool to calculate whether a chemical structure will lead to AO metabolism and at which SOM. They stress that modeling the exposure of potential SOMs to the enzyme active site is important for the prediction of AO substrates and designing an AO liability. Their results show that they correctly predicted that a compound is a substrate and at which site it is metabolized for 88% of the 535 compounds tested.(111)
    Montefiori et al.(39) investigated further the observation that the SOM can be identified by calculating point charges using DFT methods using a set of 78 substrates extracted from the literature. They confirm that this works most of the time but similarly reliable results can be achieved by calculating NMR measurables, namely the carbon electropositivity based on the chemical shift. As described in section 2.2, the mechanism of AO-mediated oxidations relies on the electrophilicity of the carbon at the site of reaction.(36,79) One simple approach to assess electrophilicity of carbons is through the measurement of the 13C shift by NMR spectroscopy, as this is directly related to the electron environment around the carbon nucleus.(7,36) Generation of the 13C chemical shifts of potential AO substrates by NMR spectroscopy will provide the best measurement of ppm values, but software such as Mestrenova (Mestrelab research, Spain) or ChemBioDraw (PerkinElmer) can provide very good, and consistent, estimate of ppm values. This is an approach we have found useful for AO SOM predictions in the past [presentation at the DMDG Open Meeting, Cambridge September 21, 2019, and/or Poster, 21st North American ISSX meeting, Providence RI]. Montefiori et al.(39) used the ChemBioDraw (PerkinElmer) to determine the chemical shift for the carbon atoms and DFT calculated chemical shielding. They found both descriptors are as good at identifying the AO SOM for azaheterocycle oxidation as DFT calculated point charges. In isolation, the calculated or measured 13C ppm values of the most electrophilic sp2 carbons cannot identify the propensity of the molecule to be an AO substrate. However, the calculated ppm values in Montefiori paper and from additional calculations carried out at UCB show a trend of greater AO susceptibility where shifts of sp2 carbons are greater than 140 ppm, although other structural facets need to be in place such as the presence of nitrogen(s) in the ring system(s).
    In summary, the SOM of known oxidative azaheterocyclic substrates can be predicted with a high degree of reliability using DFT-calculated relative energies of tetrahedral intermediates, point charges, or calculated chemical shifts. Both Cruciani et al.(111) and Montefiori et al.(36) favor the DFT-calculated point charge method due to its simplicity and ease of automation. For a drug-like compound to be an AO substrate, it should have at least one potential SOM but also at least one which is accessible to the MoCo in the catalytic site. This latter property is perhaps harder to predict, but as the number of known substrates and nonsubstrates has grown, the methods designed to do this have become more sophisticated. For example, Hayes et al.(88) used docking to the AO cocrystal structure(37) to guide chemical design in the series of pyrido[3,4-d]pyrimidin-4(3H)-one analogues (see section 6.2).

    5. Drug Design Approaches To Modulate Metabolism by AO

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Considering the broad substrate selectivity, four distinct reaction types, interspecies differences, and often significant clinical consequences (Table 1), our recommendation is to consider AO liability early in the drug discovery process, particularly in the context of drug design, as this affords the best opportunity to remove or limit the potential for AO-mediated metabolism. Many computational (section 4) and experimental (section 8) tools are available to predict and assess AO metabolism early, enabling design teams to make timely, informed decisions. Late-stage risk assessments of AO substrates are possible, and sometimes indeed necessary, but may suffer from our insufficient understanding of AO biology and its clinical translation (section 7). While oxidations of azaheterocycles (section 3.1) and amide hydrolysis (section 3.3) are of specific relevance to control of the metabolic clearance (or even prodrug design), all AO reaction types may profoundly affect developability of the compounds, for example, through bioactivation (formation of aryl-amines), interspecies differences (e.g., MIST issues), and poor in vitro−in vivo correlation (IVIVC). Although we recommend an early consideration of AO liability, our opinion is that this should not result in automatic avoidance of AO structural flags. Azaheterocycles or aromatic amides are common and versatile building blocks that may bring additional value to discovery programs, even if increasing the risk for metabolism by AO. Ideally, AO-mediated metabolism should be evaluated as a part of the multiparametric optimization process with a goal to increase overall compound quality.

    5.1. General Considerations about AO-Catalyzed Oxidations

    Most chemotypes with azaheterocyclic motifs should be evaluated for AO activity, especially if they are key pharmacophores within the chemotype (e.g., kinase inhibitors). Early accessible criteria should be used to reduce the number of specific experiments, for example, structural flags (predicted in cerebro or in silico), previously available metabolite identification results (from hepatocytes or in vivo samples), or “suspicious” discovery findings (e.g., disconnect between microsomal and hepatocyte clearance, poor IVIVC, and interspecies differences, especially absence of specific metabolites in dog). Exceptions are fully substituted azaheterocycles where AO reactions cannot occur.
    If AO-catalyzed oxidations of the chemotype are confirmed, design teams generally have four options (Figure 12): (1) to stop AO reactions, (2) to decrease the rate of AO reactions, (3) to use AO metabolite as a novel scaffold or prodrug inspiration, or (4) to proceed at risk. In all cases, identification of the exact oxidation site (section 8.3), application of computational tools (section 4), and continuous pharmacological evaluation will facilitate design. Preferably, if possible within the constraints of the chemotype and the target, design teams should aim to completely stop AO-mediated oxidations (section 5.2). Examples of confirmed AO substrates with acceptable clinical pharmacokinetics are rare, likely limited to very low turnover substrates (e.g., imatinib,(63) idelalisib,(103−108) lenvantinib(64)) or compounds where AO oxidations are not a rate-limiting step (momelotinib(22)). The current relative absence of AO substrates on the market may have been driven by several factors, such as historical use of inappropriate in vitro methods (e.g., liver microsomes instead of cytosol), wrong choice of nonclinical species (e.g., dog, which lacks expression of hepatic AO; see section 7), and high extrahepatic AO expression (section 7). Therefore, design approaches to decrease or ignore AO metabolism must be complemented by means to accurately predict human metabolic clearance (section 8.2). Lastly, if AO metabolites retain pharmacological activity, they may be used as a novel scaffold or inspiration for prodrug approach (section 5.4).
    An overview of design approaches to control AO-catalyzed oxidations is presented in Table 4. Before going into detail, readers should note that common approaches to reduce oxidative metabolism like lowering log D and introduction of EWG (e.g., fluorination) are less likely to be productive in this area. Analysis of published substrates indicate that AO-mediated oxidations are log D-independent.(7,95) The reaction mechanism of these oxidations is nucleophilic in nature (as opposed to CYP-catalyzed reactions), leading to increased reaction rates in electron-deficient heterocycles (section 2.2). The border between medicinal chemistry approaches to stop and decrease metabolism by AO is blurry, however, and mainly assigned based on success/failure rates observed in the past. All reviewed approaches are best complemented with computational tools to enable rational design and prioritization of efforts (section 4). Additionally, efforts to block or decrease AO oxidations may lead to compensatory metabolism by other drug-metabolizing enzymes, a phenomenon known as “metabolic switching”,(139) resulting in limited changes of the compound’s overall metabolic clearance, especially in vivo.(140) Although underlying mechanisms of compensatory metabolism are multifactorial, a broad substrate specificity of many enzymes may play a significant role, allowing for multiple binding poses within the active site.(139,141)
    Table 4. An Overview of Drug Design Approaches to Mitigate AO-Catalyzed Oxidations of Azaheterocycles

    5.2. Approaches to Stop AO-Mediated Oxidations

    To stop AO oxidations, several design approaches have proven successful: direct blocking of the oxidation site, replacement of the affected carbon with a heteroatom, removal of nitrogens, and saturation of aromatic and unsaturated azaheterocycles (Table 4). Additionally, in nonfused aromatic systems, reducing ring size from 6 to 5 atoms has been reasonably successful,(95) with only oxazole reported as the low turnover substrate.(109) In addition to these, modulation of ring system electronics, either by rearranging heteroatoms and substituents, or introducing EDG or/and EWG, has generally resulted in mixed success rates.

    5.2.1. Blocking of the Oxidation Site

    Direct substitution of the affected carbon reliably blocks AO metabolism(7,29,51,74,88,93,95) but often disturbs key interactions with the target and diminishes potency.(29,93) Therefore, selection of blocking groups should carefully consider potency SAR as well as physicochemical properties and safety profile of the chemotype. Even if not actively contributing to potency, substitutions with common alkyl groups (e.g., methyl, ethyl, cyclopropyl, etc.) will reduce ligand efficiency and may be contraindicated in lipophilic chemotypes, leading to diminished solubility and increased non-AO metabolism.(35) Difluoromethyl group (−CHF2) can be introduced with a “litmus test” (section 8.4),(142) providing a convenient means of both testing and blocking AO metabolism. Substituents like methoxy,(29,95) amino,(29) and fluoro(29,51) previously gave balanced results in terms of preservation of physicochemical properties and blocking AO metabolism. Substitution with an amino group leads to aryl-amine structures that may undergo bioactivation and increase risks for genotoxicity.(143) Similarly, substitutions with chlorine or cyano groups result in electron-deficient azaheterocycles that may be prone to chemical or metabolism based nucleophilic attack that can be detected in the reactive metabolite glutathione (GSH) trapping assays.(144)

    5.2.2. Replacement of Carbon with a Heteroatom

    Replacing the affected carbon with nitrogen was successful in a series of pyridine analogues (pyridine → pyridazine), effectively blocking the site of AO metabolism (Figure 20).(7,65,66) A similar approach was helpful in UCB’s internal project (isoquinoline → cinnoline; data not shown). This approach may preserve key interactions with the target and even help improve physicochemical properties like log D and solubility. As a disadvantage, introduction of an additional heteroatom may shift or introduce new sites of AO metabolism. For example, in a series of 7-azaindole analogues (oxidized in the position 2), replacement of affected carbon with nitrogen (7-azaindazole analogues) did not stop AO oxidations but only served to shift the affected site within the core (Figure 17).(93) Comparable AO “metabolic switching” is expected if quinoline or isoquinoline cores (oxidized in positions 2 or 1, respectively) are replaced with cinnoline, opening new potential sites of AO oxidation in positions 3 and 4. Additionally, introduction of new heteroatoms into unsaturated ring systems will increase polar surface area and hydrogen bond acceptor count, generally affecting both passive permeability(145) and efflux transporter liabilities of the chemotype.(146,147)

    5.2.3. Removal of Nitrogens

    Phenyl rings (or other carbon homocycles) and heterocycles without nitrogen were not reported as AO substrates, even if strongly electron-deficient carbons are present (see section 3.1). This approach was applied in the imidazo[1,2-a]pyrimidine series by removing nitrogen in position 7 to form a imidazo[1,2-a]pyridine system (Figure 21 C).(95) Although nitrogen removal stopped AO metabolism, the resulting analogue was more lipophilic (cLogP 5.51 vs 4.51), translating into higher CYP-mediated metabolism and lower solubility.(95)

    5.2.4. Saturation of Aromatic Azaheterocycle

    As most AO oxidations are affecting aromatic azaheterocycles, the removal of aromaticity, or at least partial saturation, usually stops AO metabolism. The exceptions are AO-catalyzed oxidations of iminium ions formed by initial CYP- or FMO-catalyzed oxidations of nonaromatic heterocycles (see section 3.1). This approach was successful in a series of imidazo[1,2-a]pyrimidine analogues where saturation of the 6-membered aromatic ring stopped AO oxidation (Figure 21F).(95) Removal of aromaticity may affect geometry of the compounds or remove π−π stacking interactions, however, diminishing the potency.

    5.2.5. Reduction of Ring Size

    On the basis of analysis of reported substrates, most AO oxidations occur on the 6-membered azaheterocycles (Figures 4 and 5, Table 2). Although ring size generally impacts susceptibility to AO oxidations, the distinction should be made between monocyclic and polycyclic (i.e., fused) systems. In monocyclic systems, reduction of ring size from 6 to 5 usually stops AO oxidations. For example, whereas oxidations of diazines and triazines are commonly reported (Table 2), corresponding diazoles and triazoles appear unaffected. The only reported exception is oxidation of oxazole.(109) Interestingly, isoxazole(129) and isothiazole(130) undergo AO-catalyzed reductive ring openings but not oxidations. Ring constriction approach was applied in a series of pyridine analogues: replacement with oxazole, thiazole, and isoxazole blocked oxidations (Figure 20).(7,65) Oxidations of smaller (<5) or larger (>6) monocyclic azaheterocycles are largely unexplored, opening a possibility for future research and design ideas. In contrast to monocyclics, polycyclic azaheterocycles display complex behavior. Oxidations may occur in both fused 6,6 and 6,5 systems, even on the 5-membered rings which are predominantly inert when monocyclic. As an example, benzimidazole,(92) 7-azaindole,(25) and 1H-imidazo[4,5-b]pyrazine(102) were oxidized on the 5-membered rings. The 6,6 → 6,5 approach is still worth attempting, however. In a series of zoniporide analogues, quinoline replacement with indole and indazole stopped AO oxidations, but benzimidazole was still a low-turnover substrate (Figure 23).(92) Similarly, replacement of quinoline with imidazo[1,2-a]pyridine stopped AO oxidations in a series of c-Met inhibitors,(101) a problem that previously plagued several quinoline-containing kinase inhibitors, including PF-04217903,(86,148) JNJ-38877605,(19) capmatinib,(79,80) and SGX523.(21) Interestingly, AO-catalyzed oxidations of fused 5,5 systems are not reported, providing a design opportunity.

    5.3. Approaches to Decrease Rates of AO-Mediated Oxidations

    As exemplified by several discovery projects,(7,24,29,86,93,95) azaheterocycles metabolized by AO are often key pharmacophores that cannot be easily modified without a significant loss of pharmacodynamic activity. Common approaches to stop AO-mediated metabolism, mentioned in the previous section 5.2, may not be applicable. If this is the case, several alternative design changes are worth exploring, including modulation of azaheterocycle electronics, introduction of steric hindrance adjacent to the oxidation site, modification of distal substituents, and introduction of kinetic deuterium isotope effect (KDIE). Some of these approaches are overlapping, with some substituents affecting ring electronics, introducing steric hindrance and preventing binding to the enzyme in various degrees. In contrast to methods highlighted in section 5.2, these approaches generally have mixed success rate and often just slow down AO-mediated metabolism but do not fully stop it. As some residual AO activity will likely remain, these approaches are best accompanied by IVIVC methods to predict human metabolic clearance. Moreover, if steric hindrance or distal modifications are introduced, in silico docking to both target protein and AO may be needed to enable rational design.

    5.3.1. Modulate Electronics of the Affected Azaheterocycle

    This idea is to reduce susceptibility of the affected carbon to AO oxidations, usually by rearranging heteroatoms and existing substituents or by introducing new EDG or/and EWG but without directly blocking affected carbon or significantly reducing compound’s binding affinity to AO. As mentioned in the section 3.1, removal of nitrogens and introduction of EDGs is generally beneficial, whereas instalment of EWGs has mixed to negative effects. Outcomes may be difficult to predict in complex systems, especially if multiple heteroatoms and substituents are present. These design approaches were applied in a series of methyl-pyridine analogues (Figure 20): replacement of -methyl with electron-donating −amino or −OCH3 groups stopped AO oxidations; replacement with electron-withdrawing −CF3 slowed but did not prevent AO metabolism.(7,65) Modifications of imidazo[1,2-a]pyrimidine core by rearranging existing substituents and/or introducing new substituents (−methyl, −F, −Br) resulted in mixed success rate (Figure 21).(95) Interesting and successful example of nitrogen rearrangement approach to alter AO metabolism was provided by shifting from 1,8-naphthyridines to 1,5-naphthyridines (Figure 22).(62) In a series of quinoline analogues heavily oxidized by AO (zoniporide series), introduction of distal −methyl, −OH, and −OCH3 groups significantly reduced reaction rates (Figure 23), a shift of quinoline attachment point was unsuccessful, however (Figure 23).(92)

    5.3.2. Introduce Steric Hindrance near the Affected Carbon

    If tolerated in terms of potency, steric hindrance in the vicinity of the affected carbon may be an option. In a program to find novel c-Met kinase inhibitors, a Novartis team investigated a series of 3-substituted quinolines (Figure 24).(77) Quinoline was reported to be an important binding motif for c-Met inhibitors, with some of the previous analogues already oxidized at C2 by AO, for example, SGX523(21) and JNJ-38877605.(19) Calculations of energy required to form the tetrahedral intermediate (ΔG) and docking studies were performed in parallel. Results showed that 3-substitution can significantly impact susceptibility of quinoline to AO metabolism. Whereas smaller and electron-donating substituents (e.g., compounds 51, 53, and 71) showed high AO turnover, larger groups generally mitigated oxidations probably due to steric effects (Figure 24). Interspecies differences were also pronounced.

    5.3.3. Modify Distant Substituents to Prevent Binding to AO and/or Access to MoCo

    This approach aims to disrupt binding of compound to the AO, usually through modifications of distal substituents that are amenable to change (e.g., groups exposed to solvent or noncritical pharmacophores). If pursued rationally, this approach requires good understanding of SAR for both target and AO binding, conditions that were rarely met in practice. For example, in a series of 1,6-naphthyridine and isoquinoline analogues empirical introduction of pendant polar groups failed to reduce AO metabolism.(29) Similarly, to slow down AO-catalyzed oxidations of the imidazo-1,5-naphthyridine scaffold, distant modifications were attempted (Figure 19).(86) Whereas R2 substitutions (piperidine motif; compounds 13−19) had modest impact on half-lives in human liver S9 (t1/2 = 6.5−38.7 min), R1 substitution of pyridine with indazole significantly diminished AO reaction rates and increased half-lives to 156−158 min (compounds 21 and 23). As improved compounds were still AO substrates, and AO metabolic clearance was historically often underpredicted from in vitro data,(87,149) the team applied an empirical scaling approach based on in vitro and in vivo data from four known AO substrates: carbazeran, zoniporide, zaleplon, and PF-04217903. This analysis showed that compounds 18, 21, and 23 could have acceptable human clearance. In a series of pyridine analogues, modifications of distal substituent R1 gave mixed success: whereas ethyl-oxazole and tetrahydropyran analogues were not AO substrates, isoxazole and pyrazole analogues were metabolized (Figure 20).(7) In a imidazo[1,2-a]pyrimidine scaffold, distal modifications to pyridine ring were well tolerated from perspective of potency (Figure 21 A) but did not stop AO metabolism.(95) In a series of quinoline analogues (zoniporide series), structural variations of distal acylguanidine moiety and cyclopropyl group modulated AO reaction rates but did not stop the oxidations (Figure 23).(92)

    5.3.4. Introduce Kinetic Deuterium Isotope Effect (KDIE)

    Kinetic isotope effect is the change of the enzymatic reaction rate when atoms in the substrate are replaced by one of its isotopes, usually hydrogen with deuterium in drug-like examples.(150) On the basis of increased strength of a C−D bond compared to a C−H bond, and current understanding of AO catalytic mechanism where hydride subtraction from a substrate is likely to be rate-limiting step (see section 2.2),(43) kinetic deuterium isotope effect (KDIE) is expected to play a significant role in AO-catalyzed reactions. In principle, KDIE can be intramolecular (i.e., intrinsic) or intermolecular, referring to change in the reaction rates between two isotopes in the same molecule or two isotopes in two different molecules, respectively.
    Carbazeran (phosphodiesterase-2 inhibitor) and zoniporide (Na+/H+ exchanger-1 inhibitor) were Pfizer’s development candidates discontinued due to high clearance in humans, mostly due to AO-mediated metabolism.(12,73) As exact sites of AO metabolism were identified for both compounds, corresponding deuterated analogues were prepared and their KDIE evaluated (Figure 13A).(140) In parallel, monodeuterated phthalazine, quinoxaline, and quinoline were synthesized to mechanistically investigate intramolecular KDIE (phthalazine and quinoxaline have two identical C−H bonds attacked by AO; if one is substituted with C−D, intramolecular KDIE can be determined accurately) (Figure 13 B).
    Determined in liver cytosol of human, rat, and guinea pig, intramolecular (phthalazine and quinoxaline) and intermolecular (carbazeran, zoniporide, and quinoline) the KDIE were 4.7−5.1 and 3.6−6.1, respectively.(140) Further, on the basis of steady-state experiments with quinoline, deuteration mainly reduced Vmax of the reaction without significantly affecting the Km. Taken together, these results suggested that AO reaction mechanism is conserved across species, with C−H bond cleavage being the rate-limiting reaction step. In contrast to liver cytosol, KDIE values observed in more complex in vitro systems, such as hepatocytes or cofactor supplemented liver S9 fraction, were generally lower, especially in human hepatocytes (KDIE 1.5−1.9). Observed reduction in apparent KDIE values may be related to alternative metabolic routes present in hepatocytes (e.g., FmAO < 1), such as glucuronidation of carbazeran, or “metabolic switching” phenomena commonly occurring when substrate is competing for multiple biotransformation pathways. In vivo results with carbazeran and zoniporide revealed further complexities, with observed KDIEs varying depending on the test compound (carbazeran vs zoniporide), administration route (oral vs intravenous), and animal species (Hartley guinea pigs vs Sprague−Dawley rats).(140) For example, deuteration of carbazeran resulted in approximately 2- and 21-fold AUC increase in rats and guinea pigs, respectively, whereas deuteration of zoniporide showed no significant effect in vivo. Such differences could be rationalized in terms of overall clearance level in relation to hepatic blood flow (CLplasma vs Qh) and fractional clearance by AO (FmAO). Considering the differences in AO expression between rat and guinea pig, however, both in terms of isoforms expressed and their tissue localization (see section 7.1), we speculate that these species-specific effects on PK might be also partially explained by different substrate-specificities of the various rat and guinea pig AO enzymes. The authors concluded that clear understanding of the overall clearance rates and mechanisms is important; deuteration of AO substrates could help pharmacokinetics only for low-to-moderate clearance compounds and if non-AO clearance mechanisms are not predominant.(140)
    JNJ-38877605, the inhibitor of c-Met kinase, was discontinued due to renal toxicity caused by accumulation of the AO-formed quinolin-2-one metabolite despite the acceptable human plasma clearance of 12 mL/min/kg (Figure 13C).(19) Replacement of a hydrogen atom with deuterium at C2 of the quinoline ring led to apparent reduction of AO metabolism in monkey liver S9 fraction (without NADPH); the reaction rates were not determined, unfortunately.(78) A subsequent pharmacokinetic study in cynomolgus monkeys found decreased levels of the AO metabolite and 1.88-fold increase in parent AUC compared to JNJ-38877605, indicating that deuterium replacement significantly reduced AO metabolism in vivo.(78)
    VX-984, an inhibitor of DNA-dependent protein kinase discovered by Vertex and currently developed by Merck, is another example of KDIE applied to reduce AO metabolism (Figure 13D). Although details are not published at the time of writing, the 4,6-dideuteriopyrimidine motif is thought to reduce AO liabilities (https://clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/show/NCT02644278). Similarly, MET763 was developed as a deuterated analogue of MET401 (Figure 13 E), a c-Met inhibitor constructed around the novel triazolopyrimidine scaffold affected by AO oxidations.(98−100)

    5.4. Application of AO Oxidations for Prodrug Design or Novel Scaffolds

    AO oxidations are often rapid in vivo, with rates of metabolic clearance reaching or even exceeding liver blood flow. If oxidative metabolites retain pharmacological activity, they may be used as an inspiration for prodrug approach or a novel scaffold. For example, lactam (pyridone-like) metabolites are often stable to further metabolism (authors’ unpublished observations) but may suffer from lower solubility and permeability. Decreased solubility of lactam metabolites is often related to changes in pKa: from slightly basic in many common azaheterocycles to generally neutral in corresponding lactams.
    Famciclovir, a substituted purine analogue, undergoes hydrolysis and oxidation in humans to form the active antiviral drug, penciclovir (Figure 14A).(33) Because of the combination of efficient famciclovir absorption and fast presystemic metabolic conversion, overall human bioavailability of penciclovir is high, 77%.(151) The oxidative step was initially attributed to XO, mainly based on famciclovir’s structural similarity to 6-deoxyacyclovir, an attempted prodrug of acyclovir with confirmed XO involvement.(152) Subsequent studies showed that oxidations of famciclovir and 6-deoxipenciclovir (hydrolyzed intermediate) are catalyzed by AO (from human, guinea pig, rabbit, and rat liver), with minimal contribution from XO.(33)
    5-Fluoro-2-pyrimidinone was proposed as a prodrug of 5-fluorouracil,(32) an antitumor agent with inconsistent bioavailability in humans (Figure 14B).(153) Prodrug was oxidized to 5-fluorouracil by liver AO of humans, rats, and mice; oxidations did not occur in the intestinal tissues, however.(32) PK studies in mice showed good bioavailability of 5-fluoro-2-pyrimidinone (78−100%), followed by a relatively slow conversion to 5-fluorouracil over the course of several hours.(32) Fasudil, an isoquinoline-containing inhibitor of Rho-associated kinase, is rapidly oxidized to an active metabolite hydroxyfasudil, effectively providing a prodrug approach (Figure 14C).(34,81) In vitro, fasudil was oxidized by AO to hydroxyfasudil by the human and rat liver S9 but not by dog liver S9.(81) In healthy volunteers, fasudil was practically quantitatively converted to hydroxyfasudil, with in vivo concentrations of the prodrug (fasudil) remaining low.(154)
    Inhibitors of c-Met kinase often incorporate quinoline as the key pharmacophore, leading to numerous examples of AO metabolism (Table 2). Inspired by AO metabolism, methyl-isoquinolinone was suggested as a suitable replacement scaffold.(31) In an effort to find positive allosteric modulators of muscarinic acetylcholine subtype 4 receptor, a series of thieno[2,3-c]pyridines were discovered and found to be affected by AO oxidations.(94) As resulting pyridone metabolite retained potency, the team used AO metabolism as an inspiration for further exploration, eventually leading to thieno[3,2-e][1,2,4]triazolo[4,3-a]pyridine tricyclic analogues with improved properties.(94)

    5.5. Considerations of AO-Catalyzed Aldehyde Oxidations

    Although aldehydes are rare in drug-like molecules, they are often formed as intermediates after oxidations of primary alcohols or terminal alkyl groups.(8,15,155,156) At this stage, AO may play a role in further oxidation to carboxylic acid (Figure 6C,D), often in synergy with enzymes that share a similar function, like ALDH and XO. Even if AO involvement is limited to a single step in a multistep pathway, it may affect the overall reaction equilibrium, leading to interspecies differences in metabolite exposure (MIST issues) or problems in IVIVC. In the case of imrecoxib, a stepwise oxidation of the terminal methyl group resulted in the major carboxylic acid metabolite, accounting for 68% of the systemic exposure in humans (Figure 6C).(8) The acid metabolite was also major in rat plasma.(157) In vitro incubations revealed differences in metabolic pathways between rats and humans, however. In humans, initial oxidations to alcohol and aldehyde were catalyzed by CYP3A4/CYP2D6, but subsequent aldehyde oxidation to acid (rate-limiting step) was mainly catalyzed by AO.(8) In rats, oxidation to acid was already occurring in liver microsomes and was NADPH-dependent, suggesting limited involvement of AO.(158) The situation was further complicated by poor metabolite IVIVC in humans: acid metabolite was minor in vitro but major in vivo. Possible explanations are disbalanced role of reductive enzymes in vitro or extrahepatic AO metabolism in vivo.(8) These examples highlight that AO-catalyzed aldehyde oxidations may play an indirect (or “silent”) role in drug design, mainly through potentiation of interspecies differences and poor IVIVC. Design teams may address these concerns either through structural modifications (e.g., replacement of terminal −CH3 with −CF3 or −CHF2) or timely identification of AO-driven pathways and challenges they may bring.

    5.6. Approaches to AO-Catalyzed Amide Hydrolyses

    As amide functionality is both very common and often critical for function in drug-like molecules, avoidance is unlikely to be a sensible approach despite the potential for AO-mediated hydrolysis. Therefore, our recommendation is to guide chemical design based on available discovery data (in vitro and in vivo), including metabolic clearance in AO-competent systems (see section 8.1), metabolite identification, interspecies differences, and IVIVC. If AO involvement in amide hydrolysis is confirmed, the consequences are usually 2-fold: (a) high human metabolic clearance and interspecies differences (as exemplified by GDC-0834(9)) and (b) potential release of aryl-amine (aniline-like) metabolites that may undergo bioactivation and contribute to adverse effects.(121) As already mentioned in section 3.2, relatively little data is available on SAR of AO-mediated amide hydrolysis (Figure 7), making rational design decisions challenging. One approach is to keep the amide group intact but alter the structures of amine or acyl moieties to stop or decrease AO-catalyzed hydrolysis. An alternative approach is to replace the affected amide with a suitable isostere (or bioisostere; if amide contributes to biological function). It should also be emphasized that AO is not the only enzyme contributing to amide hydrolysis. These reactions can be catalyzed by various hydrolytic enzymes(53) or even occur nonenzymatically, for example, under acidic conditions of the stomach. Therefore, new designs should be based on an overall balance of available evidence and properties, considering both hydrolysis pathways and potency SAR of the chemotype.
