    A study of 75 amides highlighted that aromatic amides are more susceptible to AO hydrolysis compared to aliphatic ones and that structure of the amine (or aniline/aryl-amine) part plays a greater role in the hydrolysis rate.(28,159) Substitutions of aryl-amines in meta positions with EDG and EWG groups increased and decreased propensity toward AO hydrolysis, respectively. Substitutions of ortho and para positions generally reduced hydrolysis regardless if EDG or EWG was introduced.(28) Tertiary amides, sterically hindered and less flexible anilines or aliphatic amines, were also generally stable (Figure 7A).(28) In contrast to aniline moiety, the structure of acyl moiety generally had less impact on the hydrolysis rates: furane, indole, 2-methylenindole, (3-fluorophenyl)propane, cyclohexane, pyrazine, and pyridine were all substrates (Figure 7C). Tested bis-aliphatic amides were generally not substrates.(28) Comparable findings were reported during lead optimization of GDC-0834,(159) even before the team knew that AO metabolism was responsible for the observed non-CYP mediated amide hydrolysis.(9) The successful approach involved a combination of steric hindrance and electronic effects by substituting the 2- and 6- positions of the aniline (methyl and fluorine gave best results).(159)
    An alternative approach is to replace amide functionality with an amide (bio)isostere. For example, available experimental results suggest that hydrazides, ureas, and carbamates are resistant to AO hydrolysis.(28) Amide isosteres of GDC-0834, sulphonamide, and − NHCHCF3−, as well as inverted and ternary amides, reduced metabolism but also abolished potency.(159) Other commonly applied amide isosteres are trifluoroethylamine, sulphonamide, guanidine and amidine, oxetan-3-amines, cyclopropanamine fluoroethylene, and various 5-membered heterocycles, including oxadiazoles and triazoles.(160) These isosteres offer a range of physicochemical properties, geometries, and HBA/HBD motifs that should be tailored according to a project’s needs. Although synthetic investment and risk of potency decrease are higher, amide isosteres may address multiple liabilities at once, including amide hydrolysis catalyzed by several enzymes (e.g., AO and hydrolytic enzymes) and safety concerns of released aryl-amine metabolites.

    5.7. Approaches to AO-Catalyzed Reductions

    Whereas AO-catalyzed oxidations and hydrolysis are mainly discussed from the perspective of metabolic clearance, AO reductions play a somewhat different role in drug design. Metabolic clearance is now less of an issue, but challenges of safety, interspecies differences, and IVIVC remain. For example, nitro reductions lead to formation of aryl-hydroxylamines and aryl-amines, metabolites that may undergo bioactivation and contribute to a range of adverse effects, including liver toxicity(26) and genotoxicity.(16,121) Reductions of N-oxides may be counteracted with CYP/FMO-catalyzed reoxidations, resulting in complex biotransformation equilibriums that are challenging to predict from in vitro assays.(161) Lastly, reductive ring openings of isoxazole and isothiazole are infrequent biotransformation pathways that may go unnoticed and contribute to interspecies differences.(129,130) Therefore, even if functional outcomes of reductions are different, our recommendations are similar to oxidations and hydrolysis; AO reductions should be detected early and considered in design decisions as a part of the multiparametric optimization effort.
    When an aromatic nitro group is affected by AO reduction, the first step may be to assess the biological consequences of this process, for example, by in vitro safety testing of the corresponding aryl-amines, especially for hepatotoxicity and genotoxicity. If the structural motif is still deemed risky, design teams should aim to eliminate, or at least decrease, AO-catalyzed nitro reduction. It should be emphasized that genotoxicity (if likely to occur) is not evaluated from the classical therapeutic window perspective, meaning that even small amounts of genotoxic metabolites will render the drug unsafe and stop further progression. On the basis of a recent study of 11 nitroaromatic compounds, one design possibility is to increase relative electron-richness of the functionality, for example, by introducing electron-donating substituents in the aromatic ring.(11) The alternative is to replace nitro group with a suitable isostere, for example pyridine,(162) carboxylate,(163) or difulorophenyl moiety.(164) The nitroaromatic group of nimesulide, a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug exhibiting hepatotoxicity facilitated by AO-mediated reduction, was successfully replaced with pyridine.(162) Fruitful pyridine replacement of aromatic nitro group was also achieved in a series of β-adrenergic antagonists.(165)N-Oxides are relatively rare in drug-like chemical space,(166) with some examples being minoxidil, seletalisib, chlordiazepoxide, and otamixaban. If reduced by AO, formed metabolites can often be reoxidized by other oxidative drug-metabolizing enzymes (e.g., CYPs and FMOs), leading to complex equilibria as exemplified by seletalisib.(161)

    6. Examples of Discovery Programs

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    The following sections are summaries of where a variety of medicinal chemistry approaches have been employed to mitigate AO activity. The use of examples such as these should always form part of any drug design strategy, as learning from other groups’ successes and failures is one of the most successful ways to reduce the drug design cycle.

    6.1. Example of Disubstituted 1,6-Naphthyridines and Isoquinolines

    In a research program to discover cyclin-dependent kinase 8 and 19 inhibitors, 2,8-disubstituted-1,6-naphthyridines and 4,6-disubstituted-isoquinolines were rapidly oxidized by AO (Figure 15).(29) Analysis of metabolites identified C1 (isoquinolines) or C5 (1,6-naphthyridines) carbon, adjacent to nitrogen, as the main sites of AO oxidations. Formed pyridone metabolites were pharmacologically inactive, consistent with results from the ligand−target cocrystal structure showing naphthyridine nitrogen N6 interacting with the backbone −NH− of the hinge residue alanine 100. The team used incubations with HLC and chemical “litmus test”(142) (section 8.4) to design away from AO metabolism. Enzymatic oxidations and radical-based −CHF2 additions were well correlated. Initial attempts to indirectly reduce the AO metabolism, focused on introduction of distal polar substituents and reduction of log D, were unsuccessful. This result was in line with previous observations that AO metabolism is largely independent of log D (Table 4). Direct blocking of affected carbon with methoxy, methyl, difluoromethyl, or amino group was successful, but only amino substituted analogues retained desired pharmacological activity.(29)

    6.2. Example of Pyrido[3,4-d]pyrimidin-4(3H)-one Analogues

    In a search for JmjC histone lysine demethylase inhibitors, pyrido[3,4-d]pyrimidin-4(3H)-one analogues were oxidized by AO at the C2-position (Figure 16).(88) Oxidations were observed both in human and mouse liver cytosol, inhibited by raloxifene but not allopurinol, and the exact site of metabolism was identified by high resolution LC-MS and 1H NMR. Consistent with in vitro results showing AO involvement, compounds exhibited high blood clearance in mice (>liver blood flow) and poor oral bioavailability (2%). The available crystal structure of human aldehyde oxidase and Glide docking were used to guide design.(37) Direct blocking of affected C2 position with methyl or ethyl groups stopped AO metabolism and preserved potency.(88)

    6.3. Examples of Azaindole Analogues

    The quest for inhibitors of influenza viral polymerase at Vertex Pharmaceuticals led to discovery of 7-azaindole analogues that were oxidized by AO at the C2 position (Figure 17A).(93) Oxidations by AO were monitored in human liver cytosol, and the site of oxidation was determined by 1H NMR after metabolite isolation. Co-crystal ligand−target structures showed that azaindole ring is the key pharmacophore involved in hydrogen bonding with lysine 376 and glutamic acid 361. As this finding indicated that AO metabolites would be pharmacologically inactive, the team embarked on designing-out AO activity. The strategy to mitigate AO metabolism followed two directions: (a) direct substitutions of the C2-position and (b) inclusion of additional nitrogen to form the 7-azaindazole motif. Small alkyl groups (methyl and cyclopropyl) and carboxylic acid at the C2-position significantly diminished potency, but a hydroxymethyl group and oxime were well tolerated (design was helped by cocrystal structures indicating possibility for additional interactions with Glu361 and Arg332). When assayed for AO activity in human liver cytosol, all C2-substituted compounds were metabolically stable.
    In contrast to C2-substituted analogues, 7-azaindazole compounds were equipotent to corresponding 7-azaindole analogues. The 7-azaindazole analogues were rapidly metabolized and reactions were inhibited by raloxifene, however, suggesting that AO metabolism was not stopped.(93) Although this surprising result was not investigated further, incorporation of additional nitrogen may have modulated the electronics of the 7-azaindazole system, leading to novel sites of AO oxidation in the positions C4 or C6. Metabolic switching to unsubstituted carbon of pyrimidine was also possible, although less likely based on previous results from C2-substituted 7-azaindazoles.
    Similar AO-mediated C2 oxidation of 7-azaindole was previously observed for VX-509 (decernotinib), a Janus kinase 3 inhibitor in clinical development for treatment of rheumatoid arthritis (Figure 17B).(25) The VX-509 oxidative metabolite was found to be involved in clinically relevant time-dependent inhibition of CYP3A4, possibly due to covalent binding to the enzyme.(25) As human liver microsomes (a subcellular fraction that lacks AO activity) were used for CYP inhibition studies in preclinical development, drug interaction potential remained undiscover until VX-509 increased the AUC of midazolam, atorvastatin, and methyl-prednisolone by 12.0-, 2.7-, and 4.3-fold, respectively.(25)
    In a research program to find inhibitors of ataxia telangiectasia and Rad-3 related protein, 6-azaindole analogues were identified as very potent (Figure 17C).(51) Biotransformation experiments with human liver cytosols and 18O-labeled water revealed that compound was an AO substrate, but the exact structure of the metabolite was not reported. The 5-fluoro-6-azaindole analogue stopped AO metabolism and improved Caco-2 permeability.(51)

    6.4. Example of Imidazoquinoline Analogues

    In a Novartis discovery program to find inhibitors of Cancer Osaka thyroid kinase, a high-throughput screening identified a 2.6 μM hit based around 1H-imidazo[4,5-c]quinoline scaffold (Figure 18).(24) Hit-to-lead efforts to increase potency, improve kinase selectivity, reduce log D, and enhance solubility, resulted in the optimized compound with 1H-imidazo[4,5-c][1,7]naphthyridine core and low nanomolar potency. X-ray cocrystal structure with the target confirmed tight interactions of the imidazoquinoline core with several key amino acid residues. Subsequent pharmacokinetic experiments in rats showed very high plasma clearance (221 mL/min/kg), however, far exceeding the liver blood flow and preventing the execution of pharmacological studies. Mechanistic studies in bile-cannulated rats and human and rat liver S9 (without NADPH) identified and isolated a major oxidative metabolite on the C2 position of 1H-imidazo[4,5-c][1,7]naphthyridine core (Figure 18). Oxidations in human and rat liver S9 fractions were inhibited by raloxifene, a potent AO inhibitor,(134) confirming the involvement of AO.(24) Because of poor pharmacokinetics in rats, subsequent pharmacological experiments were performed in dogs, a species that lacks functional AO.(24) This example shows the need for early identification and mitigation of AO activity in the chemical series, especially if AO structural alert overlaps with the key pharmacophore.

    6.5. Example of 1,5-Naphthyridine Analogues

    A Pfizer research program to find structurally differentiated and dual phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase (PI3K)/mammalian target of rapamycin (mTOR) inhibitors, identified promising hits with imidazo-1,5-naphthyridine scaffold (Figure 19).(86) Optimization goals were to increase cellular potency and improve overall drug-like properties (metabolic stability, permeability, solubility, and log D). Incubations with human liver S9 without NADPH, inhibition by raloxifene, and metabolite isolation confirmed metabolism by AO, with the site of oxidation being C2 of the 1,5-naphthyridine scaffold.(86) As docking studies and cocrystal structure indicated that the naphthyridine ring nitrogen forms a key hydrogen bond with the hinge residue of PI3K, the team’s approach to mitigate AO metabolism was to modify distal substituents R1 and R2 without changing the 1,5-naphthyridine core itself (Figure 19).(86) Whereas R2 substitutions (piperidine motif; compounds 13−19) had modest impact on half-lives in human liver S9 (t1/2 = 6.5−38.7 min), R1 substitution of pyridine with indazole significantly diminished AO reaction rates and increased half-lives to 156−158 min (compounds 21 and 23). As improved compounds were still AO substrates, and AO metabolic clearance was historically often underpredicted from in vitro data,(87,149) the team applied an empirical scaling approach based on in vitro and in vivo data from four known AO substrates: carbazeran, zoniporide, zaleplon, and PF-04217903. This analysis showed that compounds 18, 21, and 23 could have acceptable human clearance. Finally, compound 18 was selected based on overall balance of properties despite the moderate half-life of 38.7 min in human liver S9.(86)

    6.6. Example of Pyridine Analogues

    In Pfizer’s program to find agonists of toll-like receptor subtype 7, several imidazopyridine analogues with pyridine substituents were prepared (Figure 20).(7,65) Despite a good balance of in vitro properties, lead compounds exhibited very high clearance in rat plasma (up to 144 mL/min/kg), preventing the execution of planned toxicological studies. Incubations with rat liver cytosol and inhibition by menadione confirmed oxidation of methyl-pyridine moiety by rat AO; this reaction was not occurring in human liver cytosol, however. To enable toxicological studies in rat and reduce interspecies differences, the team focused on designing-out AO metabolism in rat. Several complementary approaches were used, including (a) directly blocking or replacing site of metabolism at the pyridine, (b) modulating electronics of the pyridine, (c) introducing steric hindrance at pyridine, and (d) modifying distal substituent R1 (Figure 20). In addition to experimental studies, molecular orbital calculations were performed to estimate reaction energies for the addition of the hydroxyl anion to a range of substituted pyridines; these calculations reflected only electronic properties of the pyridine ring and did not consider steric factors.(7,40) Results showed that almost all pyridine modifications mitigated rat AO metabolism without introducing human AO metabolism. An interesting exception was a trifluoromethyl-pyridyl compound that was oxidized at the lower rate compared to methyl-pyridine (1.5 vs 11 μL/min/mg), despite the highest reactivity predicted from the calculated reaction energies. Modifications of distal group R1 resulted in mixed outcomes: whereas ethyl-oxazole and tetrahydropyran analogues were not AO substrates, isoxazole, and pyrazole analogues were metabolized.(7)

    6.7. Example of Imidazo[1,2-a]pyrimidine Analogues

    In a Pfizer program to discover selective antagonist of androgen receptor, a lead compound was identified with imidazo[1,2-a]pyrimidine scaffold (Figure 21).(95−97) Despite low clearance in human microsomes and hepatocytes, as well as satisfactory rat pharmacokinetics, incubations with human liver S9 (without NADPH) and inhibition by raloxifene indicated oxidation by AO. Ion fragmentation analysis identified imidazo[1,2-a]pyrimidine scaffold as the site of AO metabolism, although the exact position of oxidation was not determined. Because only one oxidative metabolite was observed, the team hypothesized that likely sites of AO oxidation are electron deficient carbons adjacent to nitrogens (C22, C27, and C29) if they are spatially accessible by MoCo. Several complementary approaches to mitigate AO metabolism were attempted, including modifications to distal substituents to prevent AO binding, direct blocking of carbons C22 and C29, and rearrangement and removal of nitrogens from the ring system. Distal modifications to pyridine ring were well tolerated from a perspective of potency (Figure 21A) but did not stop AO metabolism. An attempt to block AO oxidation at C22 with a methyl group was also unsuccessful, indicating that likely SoM are C27 or C29; blocking C29 with methoxy group stopped the oxidation (Figure 21B). Replacement of nitrogen in position 30 with carbon was also successful, confirming that C29 was the likely site of AO oxidation (Figure 21C). Removal of N30 led to higher microsomal clearance and lower solubility, however, exemplifying the potential shortcomings of this approach. AO oxidation persisted when nitrogen was moved from position 29 to 30, possibly due to a novel exposed site at C29 (Figure 21D). Various attempts at modulating electronics of the ring system, changing attachment point, or introducing substituents at C28 resulted in mixed outcomes (Figure 21E). Interestingly, imidazo[1,2-a]pyrimidine core was oxidized in contrast to [1,2,4]triazolo[1,5-a]pyrazine core, suggesting that electronics of the ring system can play a major role. Finally, removing aromaticity from the 6-membered ring also blocked oxidations (Figure 21F).

    6.8. Example of Naphthyridine Analogues in Azetidinyl Ketolides

    A research program to overcome bacterial resistance and improve safety of ketolide macrolides resulted in a novel series of azetidinyl ketolides (Figure 22).(62) Synthesized compounds were derivatives of telithromycin with its imidazolyl-pyridine motif replaced with various naphthyridine analogues. DMPK optimization focused on microsomal clearance and time-dependent inhibition of CYP3A4, resulting in the nomination of 1,8-naphthyridine 6q for clinical development (Figure 22). Clinical pharmacokinetics was poor, however, with achieved exposures 5-fold lower compared to those anticipated. Subsequent incubations with human liver cytosol and inhibition by raloxifene revealed AO metabolism on the [1,8]-naphthyridine moiety; the exact site of oxidation was not determined. The primary approach to mitigate AO oxidations was to modulate electronics of the affected azaheterocycle by rearranging nitrogens and introducing hydroxyl substituents. Two 1,8-naphthyridine analogues were prepared (6m and 6r), but AO oxidations persisted. The 1,5-naphthyridine analogues (6l and 6s) were not oxidized, however, and 3-hydroxy-[1,5]naphthyridine analogue was selected for further progression.

    6.9. Examples of Quinoline Analogues

    Zoniporide is an inhibitor of the sodium/hydrogen exchanger that failed in clinical trials due to high metabolic clearance, a process that was later attributed to AO-mediated oxidation of its quinoline core at the C2.(73) To understand the SAR of zoniporide oxidation, several analogues were prepared and assayed in human liver S9 without NADPH (Figure 23).(92) Half-lives of the parent compounds (t1/2) were reported as a measure of metabolic stability, and sites of oxidation were investigated by LC-MS. Structural variations included analogues of the acylguanidine moiety, cyclopropyl group, and the quinoline core. Results showed that distal modifications to acylguanidine and cyclopropyl moieties can slow down, but not completely stop, AO oxidations. To enable rational design and compound progression, this approach relies on complementary in silico tools (docking or electronic properties calculations) and IVIVC approaches to predict impact of residual AO activity on human clearance. Modifications to the quinoline core were also partially successful, even without directly blocking the SoM. Interestingly, 6-substituted quinolines were more metabolically stable (t1/2 = 120 min) and reduction of ring size (6 → 5) generally mitigated AO metabolism (t1/2 = 120 min), even if benzimidazole was a low-turnover substrate.(92)
    In a program to find novel c-Met kinase inhibitors, a Novartis team investigated a series of 3-substituted quinolines (Figure 24).(77) Quinoline was reported to be an important binding motif for c-Met inhibitors, with some of the previous analogues already oxidized at C2 by AO, for example, SGX523(21) and JNJ-38877605.(19) To assess AO metabolism, compounds were incubated with human, mouse, rat, and monkey liver cytosol without NADPH and half-lives were reported as a measure of metabolic stability. Calculations of energy required to form the tetrahedral intermediate (ΔG), and docking studies were performed in parallel. Results showed that 3-substitution can significantly impact susceptibility of quinoline to AO metabolism: whereas smaller and electron-donating substituents (e.g., compounds 51, 53, and 71) showed high AO turnover, larger groups generally mitigated oxidations, probably due to steric effects (Figure 24). Interspecies differences were also pronounced. Compound 51 showed relatively low turnover in human liver cytosol (t1/2 = 283 min) but much higher in monkey (t1/2 = 3 min). Conversely, compound 53 was relatively stable in rat cytosol (t1/2 = 229 min) but much less so in monkey and human cytosol (t1/2 = 9.1 and 88 min, respectively). As these differences may affect suitability of pharmacological and toxicological nonclinical species, early cross-species screening was a good practice.(77) The energy needed to form the tetrahedral intermediate (ΔG) did not correlate with experimental results.
    In a quest to identify novel inhibitors of phosphoinositide 3-kinase β, a team from Gilead Sciences observed a unique example of atropisomerism (stereoisomers due to hindered rotation around a single bond) affecting the rate of AO-mediated quinoline oxidations.(167) In this case, restricting the free rotation around the C−N bond connecting the two bicyclic systems led to two atropisomeric compounds (Figure 25): (M)-28 with significant AO metabolism (predicted FmAO was 69%) and (P)-28 with significantly reduced AO metabolism (FmAO was unmeasurable). By a combination of thoughtful design and serendipity, (P)-28 was also the eutomer, providing the team with an orally bioavailable compound for further studies.(167) Stereoselective AO metabolism was previously observed for RS-8359 (pyrimidine analogue) and cinchona alkaloids (quinoline analogues).(71,72)

    6.10. Lessons Learned from Discovery Programs

    As highlighted by the presented discovery programs, early identification of AO metabolism and complementary information, e.g., SoM, pharmacological activity, and cross-species variability, play a positive role toward the success of discovery programs. The variety of examples presented in this section suggests that the most straightforward and reliable approaches to design away from AO metabolism rely on direct blockade of the SoM by substitution or modification of the heterocycle system with introduction of a heteroatom. This strategy highlights the usefulness of early identification of the SoM, initially by soft-spot identification and later isolation and full characterization of metabolites (section 8.3). Alternatives and complementary approaches, such as in silico prediction or litmus test (allowing immediate blockade of the putative site) are still underutilized and their reliability remains to be assessed.
    If direct blocking or replacement of SoM cannot be applied, due to loss of potency or any other critical parameters, changing heterocycles or substituting them at remote positions to either modulate the electronic effects or introduce steric hindrance have also proved to be successful, but the SAR seems to less predictable. Additionally, these approaches often reduce, but do not completely stop AO activity, necessitating the means to predict human PK during compound optimization (section 8.2). Few remaining design approaches, such as heterocyclic ring constriction, saturation, or KDIE, have been rarely applied, perhaps indicating that design teams are less familiar with these tactics. As a warning, while looking at AO metabolism, one should remain vigilant of cross-species variability (sections 7.1 and 7.2), thus early screening is advisible.

    7. Biology of AO: Species Differences and Physiological Roles

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Why is AO metabolism often underpredicted from in vitro liver models or significantly different between species? Understanding of AO biology will help us rationalize these observations and is complementary to drug design approaches. Diversity and tissue expression of AO enzymes (section 7.1) translates into profound interspecies differences (section 7.2). Lastly, physiological role of AO is briefly reviewed (section 7.3). While excellent and comprehensive reviews have been recently written on these aspects,(1,4,5) to which the reader is referred for more details, a concise overview will be given here, with the aim of providing some basic knowledge on species and assays to select, in order to complement and drive drug design strategies.

    7.1. Diversity and Tissue Expression of Mammalian AO Enzymes

    Mammalian AOs share high sequence and protein structure similarity.(4,168) Along with the other vertebrate enzymes in this family, they have evolved from a common xanthine dehydrogenase ancestor through a series of species-specific gene deletions and pseudogenizations that led to the variety of AOX genes found in the different species today.(4,168−170) In total, four mammalian AO enzymes exist: the highest number (four) is expressed in mouse, rat, and potentially rabbit (provisional entries in the NCBI Gene database, https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/gene/, last accessed July 2019) and the lowest in humans (one).(4,170,171) The AO isoforms expressed in humans and the most common nonclinical species used in drug development, along with their tissue expression, are summarized in Table 5.
    Table 5. AO Genes and Their Expression in Humans and Nonclinical Species Relevant to Drug Development
    speciesgene symbolisoenzyme(1)accession no.tissue expression(2)ref
    humanAOX1AO1mRNANM_001159.3adrenal gland, liver, kidney, seminal vesicles, ovaries, adipose tissue, prostate, testis, pancreas, urinary bladder, thyroid, bone, trachea, esophagus, colon, endometrium, placenta, lung, heart, glial cells of spinal cord(4,172−174)
       proteinNP_001150.3adrenal gland, liver, gallbladder, pancreas, kidney; brain, stomach, duodenum, small intestine, colon, rectum, testis, seminal vesicle, placenta, skin; skeletal muscle, lung, bronchus, urinary bladder, prostate, fallopian tube, breast, endometrium, soft tissueHuman Protein Atlas, version 18.1 (data available from https://www.proteinatlas.org/ENSG00000138356-AOX1/tissue, accessed on April 13, 2019)(175,176)
           
    mouseAox1AO1mRNANM_009676.2bladder, adipose tissue, inner ear, seminal vesicles, liver, esophagus, mammary gland, lung, adrenal, heart, ovary, brain, testis, colon, kidney, thymus, choroid plexus, spinal cord, spleen, eye(4,170,171,177−179)
       proteinNP_033806lung, liver, brain, spinal cord, heart, esophagus(178,180−182)
     Aox2AOX3L1, AOH3mRNANM_001008419.2olfactory mucosa, thymus, testis, ovaries, placenta, frontal lobe, bladder, large intestine, colon(170,177,181,182)
       proteinNP_001008419.1olfactory mucosa(181,182)
     Aox3AO3, AOH1mRNANM_023617.2liver, lung, testis, lung, bladder, adipose tissue, ovaries, mammary gland, brain, kidney, heart, adrenal gland, stomach, placenta, skin(4,177,180,183)
       proteinNP_076106.2liver, lung, esophagus, skin(180−182)
     Aox4AO4, AOH2mRNANM_023631.2Harderian gland, stomach, testis, brain, placenta, lung, ovaries, thymus, stomach, skin, inner ear, tongue(4,170,177,180)
       proteinNP_076120.2Harderian gland, esophagus, stomach, skin, oral cavity(180,182)
          
    ratAox1AO1mRNANM_019363.2liver, testis, lung, uterus, adrenal gland, kidney, heart, brain, thymus(184)
     Aox2AOX3L1, AOH3mRNANM_001008522.1kidney, thymus, adrenal gland, liver, testis(184)
     Aox3AO3, AOH1mRNANM_001008527.1liver, testis, lung, heart, adrenal gland, kidney, uterus, thymus(184)
     Aox4AO4, AOH2mRNANM_001008523.1lung, kidney, uterus, thymus(184)
     unclearunclearprotein liver, lung, tongue, kidney, esophagus, stomach, large and small intestine, bile duct, trachea, heart, skin, bladder, brain(185−187)
           
    guinea pigAox1AO1mRNANM_001308442.1liver, lung, heart, testis, kidney, brain, Harderian gland, olfactory mucosa(170)
     Aox2AOX3L1, AOH3mRNANM_001278764.1kidney, Harderian gland, olfactory mucosa(170)
     Aox4AO4, AOH2mRNANM_001278780.1liver, testis, kidney, brain, Harderian gland, olfactory mucosa(170)
         
    dogAOX2AOX3L1, AOH3mRNANM_001048132.1nasal mucosa(170,188)
     AOX4AO4, AOH2mRNANM_001044749.1nictitating gland(170,188)
         
    cynomolgus monkeyAOX1AO1mRNANM_001284744.1liver, lung, kidney, lacrimal gland, olfactory mucosa(170)
     AOX2AOX3L1, AOH3mRNANM_001308400.1skin, olfactory mucosa(170)
    Briefly, the major source of AO mRNA and protein in humans are the adrenal gland and liver. Here, developmental AO expression varies, being already high in fetal adrenal(189) but very low in new-born liver, only to reach adult hepatic expression levels at two years of age.(4) Once adult expression levels are reached, the amount of total AO protein and catalytic activity in human liver shows large interindividual variability,(190−192) which does not seem to be predicted by age, race, or gender.(192) Some single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) in the human AO gene have been found to alter the catalytic activity of the recombinantly expressed enzyme,(193,194) but these effects do not seem to translate to human hepatocytes(192) and their impact in vivo and in vivo has yet to be established.
    With regard to nonclinical species, dog liver enzymes deserve a special mention. While dog liver does not express any AO form (Table 5), it does express XO,(188) which can in some cases metabolize compounds that are substrates of AO in humans to the same metabolite. This has been observed for the PI3Kδ inhibitor idelalisib for example(103,195) and could potentially result in the erroneous selection of dog as nonclinical species for PK and toxicology studies.

    7.2. Interspecies Differences in Drug Metabolism by AO

    Wide interspecies and interstrain differences in AO activity have been observed toward many AO substrates and seem to be largely substrate specific. Such species specificities likely reflect qualitative and quantitative differences in number of AO isoforms expressed, their tissue expression patterns (as described in section 7.1) and their binding sites structure.(37,89,196,197) Few studies have investigated interspecies variability in AO activity directly with recombinant enzymes due to limited availability of such systems (see section 8.1). Studies on mouse and human recombinant AO highlighted how some human AO aza-heterocyclic substrates are metabolized with similar efficiency by mAO1 (e.g., O6-benzylguanine(198)), whereas others by mAO3 or mAO3L1 (e.g., phthalazine(197,198)) and that interspecies differences are also found with respect to potency of AO inhibitors.(198)
    Variability in AO activity between species is exemplified by the oxidation of two typical AO substrates, carbazeran, and methotrexate. While rabbit liver AO completely lacks carbazeran oxidation capacity in vitro,(118,199,200) it metabolizes methotrexate with an efficiency that is orders of magnitude higher than that of other species.(89,200,201) Some more recent examples include the sodium/hydrogen exchanger 1 (NHE-1) inhibitor zoniporide, which displays a 22-fold variation in in vitro intrinsic clearance (CLint) among species, with the highest being in rabbit, the lowest in nonhuman primates, and the value in rodents being the closest to human CLint.(202) Conversely, the rate of oxidation of the monoamine oxidase A inhibitor RS-8359 by AO is highest in monkeys and humans and two orders of magnitude lower in mouse, rabbit, and rat.(71) Another recent example is the mGlu5-negative allosteric modulator auglurant (VU0424238), with the highest in vitro CLint value reported in cynomolgus monkey and rat and the lowest in humans and guinea pigs.(68−70) Finally, in vitro CLint of the epidermal growth factor receptor inhibitor BIBX1382 is highest in nonhuman primates, humans, minipigs, and guinea pigs and lowest in rats and mice, further emphasizing the wide variation in species ranking.(203) Many other examples are found in the literature, and the reader is invited to review more specific and comprehensive reports on the subject.(1,57)
    The major consequence of these broad, substrate-dependent, interspecies differences in AO activity is a substantial difficulty in predicting human PK of AO substrates based on studies in nonclinical species. Indeed, an area for future development of better predictive models for human PK of AO substrates may in fact rely on improved in vitro systems, such as hepatocytes retaining high levels of AO activity, or integrated approaches that take into account extrahepatic AO.

    7.3. Physiological Role of AO

    In addition to xenobiotic substrates, mammalian AOs have been found to catalyze the oxidation of some endogenous compounds, namely retinoic acid and pyridoxal,(56,182) although the significance of these physiological biotransformation pathways is still unknown.(56) The very high cross-species conservation of AOX1, however, suggests the involvement of this enzyme in important endogenous roles, such as vision and synaptic transmission.(168,171,182,204,205) In mouse, high expression of AOX1 at the blood−brain barrier may indicate a role for AO in protecting the brain from the entrance of xenobiotics.(171,179) In humans, the expression of AOX1 in the adrenal glands may indicate a role in the biosynthesis of steroid hormones.(4) Several studies in various cell lines have also indicated potential physiological functions for AO: a role in modulating the phospholipid and cholesterol efflux in hepatocytes through interactions with ABCA1,(205) in adipogenesis(204) and myogenesis,(206) probably through the generation of reactive oxygen species, and in epithelial barrier integrity in the lung.(207)
    Studies suggesting roles for AO in disease biology are scarce. Some have implicated AO in the pathogenesis of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, following the detection of mouse and human AO expression in the motor neurons of the spinal cord.(174,179) AO may also mediate the neurological impairments caused by molybdenum cofactor deficiency (MoCD; one of the root causes of, e.g., pediatric epilepsy),(208) possibly due to decreased levels of AO and other molybdenum-containing enzymes and consequent accumulation of their endogenous substrates. Finally, hepatic metabolism of N1-methylnicotinamide by AO has been recently proposed to be part of the pathobiology of nonalcoholic fatty liver disease, suggesting the inhibition of AO as a treatment to reduce its symptoms.(209)

    8. Experimental Assessment of AO-Mediated Metabolism

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    As only known challenges can be addressed, sound experimental assessment of AO-mediated metabolism is a prerequisite for a successful drug design. Whereas timely identification of AO substrates is a first step in the right direction (section 8.1), many projects will benefit from additional insights, especially predictions of human metabolic clearance (section 8.2) and synthesis and structural elucidation of metabolites (section 8.3). Finally, “litmus test” is a chemical reaction mimicking the catalytic mechanism of AO, enabling identification, characterization, and blocking of AO-catalyzed oxidations (section 8.4).

    8.1. Identification of AO Substrates in Vitro

    Several in vitro assays allow a qualitative assessment of AO-mediated metabolism. As AO is a soluble cytosolic enzyme, incubations with liver cytosol, liver S9 fraction, or hepatocytes are preferable.(63) Assays with liver S9 in the presence or absence of NADPH can thoroughly differentiate oxidations catalyzed by AO or XO from those catalyzed by CYPs or FMOs, which use NADPH as the cofactor. Assays run in liver S9 in the presence of H218O can be used to provide additional evidence for contributions of AO (and XO) versus CYPs, as AO and XO utilize oxygen from water rather than atmospheric oxygen to catalyze oxidations, and they can also provide information on the site of metabolism.(51,210) The role of XO, a closely related molybdo-flavoenzyme, is mostly endogenous and relates to purine catabolism.(6) However, drug metabolism by XO has been reported, with some overlapping specificity with AO: recent examples include the mGlu5-negative allosteric modulators VU0409106 in human and rat liver S9(211) and VU0424238 in rat and mouse liver S9,(69) as well as the ghrelin receptor inverse agonist PF-5190457 in human liver cytosol.(67) Additionally, some compounds may be exclusive AO substrates in species that express the enzyme, but XO substrates in dog, which does not (as might be the case for the PI3Kδ inhibitor idelalisib, see section 7.1). To discriminate between the two enzymes, allopurinol has been extensively used as a selective XO inhibitor,(119) although more recently febuxostat has been shown to provide better potency and high selectivity toward XO.(67,212)
    Assays with recombinant AO have also been suggested, as they provide direct evidence for AO-mediated metabolism.(213) While initial attempts at recombinant expression of human AO in Escherichia coli struggled to yield adequate levels of active protein expression, probably due to low MoCo incorporation,(41,190,193) a ∼100-fold increase in holoprotein expression levels was recently attained through a method combining codon optimization of the construct with in vitro chemical sulfuration of the recombinant protein.(214) Future commercial availability of such systems is warranted and will be useful in providing definitive evidence for AO-specific metabolism.
    Care must be taken when using incubations with human liver microsomes (HLM). These subcellular fractions, often used as initial screening during drug discovery phases, can reliably identify only CYP- and FMO-catalyzed biotransformation pathways, but not AO/XO-mediated reactions. However, high cytosolic contamination of HLM preparations can occur and has been found to result in detectable AO-mediated metabolism.(215) Therefore, HLM incubations with and without NADPH may be helpful in initial discriminations between AO/XO- and CYP/FMO-mediated reactions. However, due to potentially large differences in HLM preparations and residual AO activities (e.g., different batches and manufacturers), the authors would advise against this approach. In addition to minimal and variable AO activity, HLM are a poor choice for evaluation of general amide hydrolysis; many hydrolases (including carboxylesterases) are soluble enzymes located in the lumen of the endoplasmic reticulum and may be lost during tissue homogenization and subcellular fractionation.(216)

    8.2. Human Clearance Predictions for AO Substrates

    Once the AO-mediated metabolism of the compound of interest is confirmed, various approaches have been reported in the literature to measure the fraction-metabolized by AO (FmAO) to refine predictions of human in vivo clearance. While very few drugs currently on the market are AO substrates or inhibitors, therefore not posing a significant risk for AO-mediated drug−drug interactions (DDI), as more AO drug substrates make their way into clinical trials, the risks of DDI due to AO activity might increase and may eventually become clinically significant, making the correct measurement of FmAO even more necessary.(5,25,63,67,217,218)
    The current established approach for the determination of FmAO is the time-dependent inhibition of AO activity by hydralazine, either in hepatocytes or liver S9 fractions.(210,219−222) This method is not without caveats, however, as hydralazine is known to inhibit some of the major hepatic CYPs at the concentrations needed for AO inhibition.(223,224) Indeed, many compounds have been used historically to inhibit AO, with estradiol, raloxifene, menadione, chlorpromazine, and quetiapine showing the highest potency in liver cytosol(134,217,225,226) or recombinant enzyme assays.(198) However, all these compounds, except for estradiol, also inhibit major liver CYPs, more strongly than hydralazine,(222,226) while estradiol is cleared too rapidly in human hepatocytes to be used in inhibition assays.(223) Additionally, AO inhibitors like menadione and raloxifene were reported to inhibit efflux transporters,(227) potentially further confounding clearance and FmAO predictions when using hepatocytes and chemotypes affected by transporter-mediated disposition. Therefore, a truly selective and potent AO inhibitor suitable to assays in hepatocytes has yet to be reported, and this area is a subject of active research.(228) An extensive summary of AO inhibitors has been published recently by Dalvie and Di.(5)
    Regarding the IVIVE of the metabolic clearance of AO substrates, several strategies are currently applied. As in vitro enzyme assays typically tend to underestimate in vivo metabolic clearance by AO, one recommended approach is to select batches of human hepatocytes, liver cytosol, or S9 fractions with high enzyme activity toward several reference substrates with known human PK properties.(210) The results can then be used to extrapolate in vivo human clearance of the test compounds based on the generated regression lines.(210) This method can be used for quantitative clearance predictions by in vitro−in vivo extrapolation(192,221) or semiquantitative PK predictions by the “yardstick” method.(87) With this method, the compound of interest can be predicted to belong to a low-, medium-, or high-clearance group based on how it benchmarks against the reference substrates (with known human PK) used in the same batch of hepatocytes or subcellular fractions.(14,87)
    Other authors recommend the use of hepatocyte or subcellular fraction pools from as many donors as possible to be more representative of the entire human population and avoid yet unknown effects of SNPs on single-donor enzyme activity.(219) However, several AO substrates have a reported human plasma clearance higher than liver blood flow rate, which cannot be predicted by any in vitro assays using hepatocytes or liver subcellular fractions (for a very informative recent example, see Jensen et al.(14)).
    With regard to predicting human clearance of AO substrates from nonclinical species, different approaches have been recommended. IVIVC of CLint values for cynomolgus monkey, using hepatocytes in vitro CLint and in vivo clearance values from PK studies, was found to be the best approach to estimate human in vivo CLint of zaleplon, ziprasidone, and zoniporide despite still resulting in underprediction.(229) Others have suggested single-species scaling of in vivo clearance from rhesus or cynomolgus monkey to human, after finding similarly high in vivo clearance values across these three species for the AO substrate BIBX3182.(13) However, as species similarities in AO-mediated metabolism seem to be largely substrate-dependent (Choughule et al.(89−91) and section 7.1), underprediction of human clearance from PK studies in nonhuman primates can still occur, either due to species-specific extrahepatic AO activity(13) or to human-specific metabolism by AO, as it was found for the compound RO1.(14,18)
    A novel approach for the selection of the appropriate nonclinical species for PK predictions of AO drug substrates has been recently proposed by Crouch et al.(203) In their workflow, substrate CLint is initially measured in liver S9 fractions or hepatocytes from humans and several other species, including nonhuman primates, rodents, and minipigs.(203) In vitro CLint values from the nonclinical species are then used to predict human in vitro CLint by single-species scaling or multiple-species allometry. This value is then compared to the observed human in vitro CLint measured experimentally in the same system, and the species (or combination of species) that gives the best prediction is then used in in vivo PK studies. The data from in vivo PK are then used to predict in vivo human clearance by traditional allometry. Interestingly, the species combination that leads to the best estimates of human in vitro CLint (by multiple-species allometry) of the AO substrates used in this study is nonhuman primates, guinea pigs, and minipig.(203) While this approach was successfully applied to clearance predictions for the two AO substrates zoniporide and BIBX1382,(203) which have plasma clearance values higher than liver blood flow rate, it assumes that hepatic metabolism is always the major clearance route. Presumably, the clearance of compounds with a significant component of extrahepatic metabolism could still be underpredicted, considering the interspecies differences in AO tissue expression and activity described earlier (section 7).
    Finally, a novel chimeric animal model with humanized liver, the PXB mouse, has been used by some authors to predict human metabolism by AO(14,230−232) but still resulted in clearance underpredictions. Additionally, as humanization is limited to liver and even in this tissue it does not reach 100%, contributions of mouse AO to metabolic clearance are still possible and may also confound predictions.(14)
    Use of cellular or subcellular systems to provide a translatable profile of AO-mediated metabolite generation can be difficult due to the chemo- and regio-specificity of the enzyme, coupled with the variability in the expression of the enzyme in the different systems. Use of a MoCo producing E. coli-based bacterial system, ecoAO,(213,233) can provide a means by which AO metabolites can be generated in sufficient quantities for structural identification by NMR and for use as an authentic standard in any kinetic profile assay where substrate depletion alone will not provide all the relevant data.

    8.3. Synthesis and Structural Elucidation of AO Metabolites

    Early and accurate identification of AO reaction rate, type, and site of metabolism will help guide chemical design, particularly if multiple sites of metabolism are possible. For example, discovery programs that unambiguously identified sites of AO metabolism(29,88,93) generally had a better starting point for the rational design compared to programs that had tentative metabolite assignment.(51,95) Additional advantages may be gained from analytical approaches that enable differentiation between similar and overlapping pathways, especially AO, XO, and CYP, and FMO-catalyzed oxidations.
    High resolution mass spectrometry (HRMS) is employed in the majority of metabolite profiling studies, but increasingly it is being used to both quantitatively and qualitatively profile samples concurrently from in vitro and in vivo assays, termed QuanQual profiling.(234−236) This approach has been adopted at UCB and in other research organizations for in vitro profiling of AO metabolism(63) and has been shown to provide useful qualitative data from routine screening assays, such as the providing the ability to profile appearance of metabolites as well as loss of parent, with no method development, in a single analytical run. Therefore, QuanQual approach is our recommendation for routine AO evaluations, offering the option to simultaneously assess both metabolic clearance and AO reaction type/site of metabolism. For qualitative monitoring of AO metabolism, the resulting metabolites often exhibit predictable elemental gains (e.g., +O) or losses (e.g., amide hydrolysis, −O, or −2H) with corresponding mass changes, whereas MS/MS data enables early assessment of type and site of metabolism. Generic conditions for metabolite profiling by HPLC typically comprise reverse phase acidic mobile phases and C18 stationary phases. Under these conditions the AO mediated hydroxylated metabolites for heterocycles often elute later than that of the substrate due to their increased lipophilicity,(63) giving a quick indication as to the likely involvement of AO in the biotransformation of the substrate.
    Once AO involvement is confirmed and tentative metabolism site is assigned by LC-(HR)MS, it may be beneficial to determine unambiguously the site of metabolism and/or differentiate between AO and CYP/FMO-catalyzed reactions. Additional analytical approaches can be useful at this stage, including NMR, hydrogen−deuterium exchange (HDX), or “litmus test” (section 8.4). Analytical techniques can be tailored to focus on potential AO mediated metabolism based on what is known about its mechanism or the potential products of the metabolic pathways. As it is known that the source of oxygen for the AO mediated metabolism of a substrate is derived from water,(220) numerous examples exist where 18O isotope labeled H2O has been used as the aqueous component of the in vitro incubation.(23,64,211) If AO is responsible for the subsequent oxidation, the mass gain will be 17.9992 Da, giving a clear indication as to the involvement of AO, even if there is also CYP mediated hydroxylation as this would be represented by a 15.9949 Da mass gain.
    In some cases, the AO metabolism introduces exchangeable protons in metabolites, for example, pyridone-like metabolites after oxidations of 6-membered azaheterocycles, in contrast to corresponding CYP/FMO metabolism, which yields pyridine N-oxides, metabolites without exchangeable protons. In these cases, using deuterated H2O as the HPLC mobile phase,(237) or even ND3 as the nebulizing gas,(238) results in a D for H exchange and with the corresponding mass increase of 1.0066 Da per exchangeable proton.
    Because of the significant overlap in the mechanism of AO- and XO-mediated metabolism, these analytical approaches to structural identification, such as incorporation of 18O from H218O, could also be employed in XO profiling,(33,211,239) once an XO-mediated pathway has been differentiated from AO or CYP/FMO (see section 8.1).

    8.4. Litmus Test

    Although enzymatic in vitro approaches(67) (e.g., cellular or subcellular systems described in section 8.1) are the most physiologically relevant assays to assess AO-mediated metabolism, these systems may neither have the capacity to generate sufficient levels of metabolites for isolation and structural elucidation nor the throughput to test large number of compounds in discovery settings. The so-called “litmus test” approach has been developed to address these challenges.(142,240) Inspired by catalytic mechanism of AO oxidations, the nucleophilic attack on electropositive (electron-deficient) sp2 carbons, a chemical “litmus test” was proposed to rapidly evaluate susceptibility to AO metabolism(142) Radical-based C−H functionalization with bis(((difluoromethyl)sulfinyl)oxy)zinc (DFMS) reagent was applied in the presence of TBHP, resulting in −CHF2 adducts on electron-deficient sp2 carbons (Figure 26).(240,142) On the basis of evaluation of eight known AO substrates, the tested chemical reaction predicted sites of AO oxidations well, apart from compounds where binding to enzyme plays a major role in oxidation rates (e.g., large quinoline-based azetidinyl ketolide, section 6.8).(142)
    The resulting CHF2 coupled product can be generated in amounts suitable for unambiguous identification by NMR. Identification of the site of CHF2 addition can then be correlated with the site of the oxidative metabolism by AO. In the case of the litmus test assay, the introduction of a CHF2 moiety onto the molecule(s) can provide a specific and sensitive handle from which one can perform the reaction in situ in an NMR tube and employ heteronuclear NMR techniques, such as 1H−13C or 19F−13C heteronuclear single quantum coherence spectroscopy (HSQC), to identify the site of metabolism without any purification steps. This has been employed at UCB to assist structural identification of products from the litmus test approach (Figure 27).
    In addition to providing structural information, it can also be employed as a simple, late-stage functionalization approach to generate compounds with the site of AO metabolism blocked, and therefore potential drug-like molecules in their own right. Despite its utility, it is important to keep in mind that the litmus test has the propensity to generate false positives as it is purely a chemical approach and does not factor in the binding to the AO enzyme.

    9. Conclusions

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Considering broad substrate selectivity, complex biology, and potentially serious clinical consequences, our recommendations are

    • An early consideration of AO-mediated metabolism (e.g., in hit-to-lead and lead optimization), but not an automatic avoidance of AO structural flags, many of which are valuable and common building blocks (e.g., various azaheterocycles and amides).

    • A timely and rational application of drug design to control AO-mediated metabolism (stop, decrease, or utilize for prodrug design) supported by complementary approaches: computational and experimental assessment and understanding of AO biology.

    • Although designing-out AO-mediated metabolism is the safest way to enable clinical progression, successful development of AO substrates is still possible and precedented in the literature. This task relies on accurate predictions of human metabolic clearance and overcoming of other development challenges, especially interspecies differences and metabolite safety.

    ARTICLE SECTIONS

    Abbreviations Used
    ADH

    alcohol dehydrogenase

    ALDH

    aldehyde dehydrogenase

    AO

    aldehyde oxidase

    AOH

    aldehyde oxidase homologue

    CLint

    Intrinsic clearance

    CYP

    cytochrome P450

    EDG

    electron-donating group

    EWG

    electron-withdrawing group

    FmAO

    fraction metabolized by AO

    FAD

    flavin adenine dinucleotide

    FMO

    flavin-containing monooxygenases

    HLC

    human liver cytosol

    IVIVE

    in vitro−in vivo extrapolation

    IVIVC

    in vitro−in vivo correlation

    KDIE

    kinetic deuterium isotope effect

    MOA

    mechanism of action

    MIST

    Metabolites in Safety Testing

    MoCD

    molybdenum cofactor deficiency

    MoCo

    molybdenum pyranopterin cofactor

    MAO-B

    monoamine oxidase B

    MPTP

    1-methyl-4-phenyl-1,2,3,6-tetrahydropyridine

    PK

    pharmacokinetics

    PSA

    polar surface area

    SNP

    single-nucleotide polymorphism

    SAR

    structure−activity relationship

    SOM

    site of metabolism

    UGT

    UDP-glucuronosyltransferases

    XO

    xanthine oxidase
